Pretty nice for the style, but missing a few large whiffs. Medium-bodied; Mild taste throughout - coriander seed and lots of it, very strong up front. Following soon behind with some nutmeg and wheatie characteristics - the yeast is somewhat noticeable. Aftertaste is light and airy - only some of the malt is noticeable, none of the hops and none of the sweetness. Overall, a good attempt at the style - I thought this was better from the appearance & aroma than it actually was. However, all-said, I would recommend people trying this beer. I sampled this 75 cL bottle purchased at Merchants in Dearborn, Michigan on 04-September-2005 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

Bottle.  Pours hazy yellow with white fizzy diminishing head - very pretty.  The aroma is interesting, it reminds me of Belgian beers. The aroma has notes of perfumey flowers, cheese, and lemon.  The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, and lightly bitter. The finish is acidic, with some orange juice and peel, and grapefruit.  The palate is light to medium, dry, fizzy, and finishes slightly astringent.  Overall this is a very good, interesting beer thats a great deal at $7/750ml

Bottle pours cloudy golden color with a thin white head.  Has an aroma of funk, spices, and yeast.  Medium light mouthfeel.  Flavor follows the nose with funk, spices, and a light dry finish.  Just like the bottle says!  Overall a real nice brew.

750 mL bottle purchased from Chuck Evans Liquor Store in Bowling Green, KY.  Poured a slightly hazy yellow/gold color with a huge, bubbly white head.  Aroma was of spices.  Coriander and citrus dominted the nose.  The flavor was sour and funky, with a slight oaky character.  I really enjoyed this beer.  This makes me anxious to try some of the other JP brews.  Great beer.

Bottle.  Pours a light gold with a lot of floaters and a fast receding white head.  Nose is coriander, spicy yeast and a touch of funk.  Taste is  coriander and a touch of citrus upfront, but that morphs into sour vegetables and funky yeast.  Lighter, prickly mouth feel.  Not one of the better JP brews.

Bottle. Pours yellow gold with a white head. The aroma is a bit citric with spices and brett. The flavor has a light lemony citrus with bretty funk and a touch of spice. Very well balanced and refreshing with a nice dry and tart finish.

Bottle from secret santa. This is a beer that I would have never thought to attempt to obtain for whatever reason. I am excited this was sent to me! Tartness dominates the aroma. Lots of oak with really hard to discern spice and fruit. Pours a bright golden yellow with a great fizzy white head that is chillin the fresh way. Wow this is very unique. Initial tartness is followed by some spicy fruit wit characteristics. This is washed away by the rather strong carbonation and only a tart oak flavor lingers. Intersting JP take on style.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 Hazy gold with a long lasting soapy white head. Nose is geuze-light: pungent and tart with leather, must, strong lemon. Flavor is more standard white: spices, wheat, lemon. Mouth is a little over carbonated, yet light, crisp, and refreshing. Finish is short, dominated by lemon. Not very complex or coherent, but refreshing and rather nice.

wow, i forgot how much i really enjoyed this brew until i started going through my backlogs, this one was fun! ... poured a pale golden colour, good constent head ring .. zesty with a slight funk .. clean and crisp .. sweet, lght barnyard, honey .. what a nice take on a witbier from JP... a sexy sexy clean easy drinking brew, great to start the day off with..

Sampled more than one time at GABF 08, slight cloudy yellow hue, with an off-white head, yeasty, brett funky nose of wet oakiness, barnyard,with a wheaty malt accent, some acidic, musty citrus lemon, orange peel esters, with a light spicy coriander note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with yeasty,funky, fruity, sour, tart character, with an acidic lemon zestiness, and faint coriander orange pulp flavor with a hint of sour green apples, within a wet oaky, winey accent, leading towards a fruity lemony sourness finish.

75 cL bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild brett-ish citric and dry wheaty with a mild spice note. Wineous dry and citric flavoured, lending towards a dry white wine and with a smooth wheaty base flavour. Light spice accent. Light barnyard note on the back of the nose. Medium dry to dry and spiced into the finish. Nice one.

Bottle from Canal’s in Lawrenceville.  Hazy light sunflower supporting a pretty tall white head.  Spicy and slightly sour aroma.  Crisp flavors with a nice balance of herbal spice and fruit and an interesting interplay of sweetness and tartness.  Mildly carbonated and moderately silky mouthfeel and a very clean, dry finish.

Bottle. 10 cl. sample. Pours a hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma is tart with yeast. Notes of hops as it warms. Same flavour. Finish is a white wine bitterness. Too much carbonation for my liking. 28-10-08.

Had this brew at G.A.B.F. 08’.  Aroma is a very sour scent.  Color is a hazy yellow with a good head.  Taste is sour with a little coriander and a dry after taste.  Its an OK White but not one of the better ones.
So pale here is almost a green tinge.  Bright spice and sea air aroma.  Very dry with a hint of banana, with gooseberry tartness.  Good for this style of beer.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours hazy yellow, slightly pale.  bit, bubbly, white head. Aroma is nice, good coriander, some oaky tartness and wheat. Not as sweet as many other wits. Rather dry mouthfeel - not impressive in fullness. Flavour is lightly sweet, light fruitiness, good oranges. There still remains some oakiness throughout. This is a good wit, but nowhere near the best Belgian ones.

tasting at keg and barrel, I seem to be drawn to JP beers, b/c I find that they are all solid brews.  I’m not a huge fan of wits, but this was extremly nice.  typical smell, grassy cloves etc.. taste was tart with a banana aftertaste.  carbination was awsome, not too heavey.

Batch 233,234. Pours cloudy straw color with off white head. Aromas of wheat, corriander and lots of JP funkiness. Flavors of wheat, lemon and some sourness. Light to medium body with lots of carbonation and a dry finish.

Bottle 75 cl. Huge dense fin bubble white head that really lasted. Excellent display of lacework. Cloudy pale yellow color with quite big particles in flow. I really enjoyed this one, and thought it was a very nice take on a Belgian White! Aroma was a mix of sour and complex fruity notes with a twist of spice. The orange peel and coriander was very present. Also grapefruit-lemon like over the palate. The spicy edge gave it a medium like body with a lively carbonation and dry texture. Moderated acidic and sweet flavor. Dry spicy grape like fruity finish. I really enjoyed this one!

Pours a very pale pils yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma is distinctly of sour funk and apples. Taste is faintly of pilsener, orange, and some spicing, but mostly of delicious sourness. Surprising amount of body for a sour and for such low alcohol. A little too bubbly, but that is to be expected, especially since I’ve been cellaring it for awhile. Nice dry, refreshing finish. Delicious, a very nice brew. Wish it were more available/cheaper.

Pours a light and somewhat cloudy with a nice firm layer of a head. Great lacing, thick and present. Sour apple aroma with some fresh peach. cherries, and apricots. The aroma is delightful and fragrant. 
Sweet cherry candy flavor upfront, followed by sour apricot with some raspberries and peach. Beautiful bouquet of flavor.
Palate is smooth and well balanced, so interesting and easily drinkable. 
Wonderfully crafted, I throughly enjoyed it.

(Bottle) Pours hazy yellow to golden with white head. The aroma is citric and spicy up front with tones of lemon, mild lime, orange peel, coriander, ginger and mild white pepper. Light yeasty undertones of moldy basement and earthy barnyard. A touch of herbal hops and light toasted malt are also present. Just a whisper of oak wood. The flavour begins with a light toasted malt sweetness alongside some light grassy hops and a light acidic touch. The finish is dry with light coriander/ginger spiciness and a medium lemony/orange peel citric sting. The mouthfeel is light and clean without being too watery with perfect carbonation. Tiny tart. Light to medium bodied.

Bottle sampled on 09/26/08 at Night of the Funk.  Pours a cloudy yellow with a white head.  Aroma of sour wheat, slight citrus, and slight hoppiness.  Flavor of the same sour wheat, Belgian yeast, with a super sour finish.  Almost Berliner Weisse-like with the tart wheat notes.  Tasty witbier!
Bottle from 08 Night of the Funk. Aroma of a bretted up wit. Flavor the same. Some citrus. It’s tasty, but uninspiring.
Bottle 75 cl, thanks ekstedt. Golden with large, white head, somewhat hazy. Light, refreshing aroma dominated by citrus and spices. The taste is equally refreshing, somewhat sour. Light mouthfeel.
Bottle (75 cl) from Ølbutikken. Fruity with notes of orange and apricot, lemon, some wood, some Orval flavours (Brett?). Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation. Nicel balance, dry finish.

Not a very good beer. Appearance was orange-y and cloudy with fairly minimal head. Aroma was striking - there was a lot of stinky feet or stinky cheese (isovaleric?) smell going on here, which I found fairly unpleasant (despite a fondness for cheese). Flavor was more distinctly orange-peel and witbier-like, although the sweat and cheese aroma persisted into the flavor. Mouthfeel was pretty astringent, particularly for a beer with such a low ABV. I did not find this to be very drinkable.

I would not recommend this beer.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2011 Bouteille brune de 12 oz. Arômes de blé, de citron et de levure "funky". Robe jaune pâle,légèrement trouble et légère mousse. Plutôt mince en bouche, on retrouve lacidité du blé, un goût dagrumes (pelures dorange et citron) et une touche marquée des levures sauvages. Très rafraîchissant, une petite cousine de la Blanche de lErmitage de Hopfenstark.

Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow with a good frothy white head and a nice amount of sediment. Smell is bright with hints of lemons, zest, spices, and bread dough. Taste is very clean hint of citrus and spices playing nicely off of one another. Palate is nice tangy and bubbley up front with a nice dry finish.

Light orange color and very cloudy with a really nice foamy white head.  Smell is tart, spiced, fruits, and yeast.  Taste has some sourness, fruits, spices, and a dry finish.  Good carbonation level.  Good beer.
pours a hazy yellow with residual yeast sediment. Aroma of yeast, citrus, and tangy lemon. Flavor is very tart, very interesting and nice. Dry finish, pretty nice palate. Real nice beer.

Pours hazy yellow with a veneer of a head. Aroma is spice, and tart citrus. Flavor is tart with lots of citrus, but a definite sweet aspect as well. Very flavorful and well balanced. Palate is a bit thin- but thats just the style. Smooth, coating finish.
GTMW!  Hazy gold pour with a small white head.  Lemon and pepper aroma.  Flavor is similar with orange peal,  oak.  Slightly sour finish.

This was one of those "just because it cost more, doesn’t make it incredible" buys. Pours a bright hazey golden orange colour with a full white, whip cream like head. Noticeable amount of sediment, aroma is fruity- orange peel like, corander seeds and fresh cut flowers. Mouthfeel is light, and somewhat silky. Taste is soft and wheaty, with a touch of spice, lemon zest and honey dew melon. The unfortunate thing is, it sort of resembled a sorgum wheat beer- and so that is what turned me off. However, since it is unpasteurized, it wouldn’t suprise me if this beer somehow got mixed up in the heat and cold of deliveries a few times too many.

Bottle (thanks Beerlando). Cloudy pale yellow, extremely carbonated with a big white head that laces nicely. Peachy-funk nose, some peppery notes. Starts out with a restrained brettanomyces profile that becomes more pronounced as it warms, but never overpowering. Light fruit esters and spices, some floral character. Refreshingly tart and musky without much depth. Soft mouthfeel that still engulfs the palate.

Bottle. High fluffy but long lasting white head. Hazy light yellow body. Lemon oranges aroma with herbal and hay notes. Lwmon, grapefruit, corander flavor, relatively acidic and far from being sweet. Hgh carbonation and a long bitter aftertaste. Pleasant surprise.
Bottle (Batch 285) - shared with Mette & Mikkel. Cloudy yellow - white head. Citrus, hoppy, light sour, yeasty, acid, fruity, spidersweb, dusty, sharpness, light wood. Ok.

Bottle (750ml) from Belmont Station in Portland, OR--Poured a light soapy yellow-white body with a thick rocky white head.  Spicy, fizzy, effervescent with some sharp hoppy citrus notes.  First sip tingled as it passed my nose passage.  Great mouthfeel with prickly complexities.  Finished mildly tart and dry.  On of the best Belgian wits I have had to date.
Sampled on tap at The Raleigh Times. Milky gold in appearance. Hints of grapefruit, sour grass, and white grapes on the nose. Taste of sour apples, white wine. Not my thing.

Pours gold with a fizzy head. Aroma has plenty of spices, with a refreshing lightness. The flavor is pretty good, but not too amazing... it was a good beer, but nothing to write home about. Not worth the money.

750 from Mckean and Charles in Maine.  Shared with Cyn in the new Allagash glasses we got the other day.  Paired with some chimay cheese.  Pours cloudy gold with a 3 finger bright white head.  Sweet light nose.  Sweet fruity taste.  Very nice overall.  Nice wit, couldn’t find my bottle in my cellar a ways back, now I can let it hide.

Light yellow body with a cascade-like white and wide head. The nose is full of citrus-fruits and a little like a pissoir. The palate is pretty waterish and not very sparkeling but dry. I taste nectarines, green grapes and a little spices. Not much of a finish

Pours a straw color with some bits of particulate.  Aroma is a bit tart, with a bit of hay, and some yeastiness.  I’m surprised by the taste......has some tart and sourness, with bits of orange peel and coriander.  Seems like it has some hints of a Berliner Weisse.  Not too shabby....better than I expected.

Thanks to Crizay for this most eventful witbier.   Pours a cloudy straw color with a big white fluffy head that lasts forever.  It laces too, sometimes, so extra points for that.  Aroma is definitely tart with wild yeasts.  Smells of oak, mustard, italian dressing, with some slight wit tendancies behind that (grain, coriander, etc.).  Flavor is tart as well, which is no surprise.  Definitely strong on the oak, mustard, vinegar, with some orange and more defined wheat.  Finishes earthy with a bread crust, wood barrel and sorta horseraddish spiced aftertaste (though mellower than that sounds).  Light bodied, but not lacking in feel, the carbonation is quite lively.  Good stuff!
Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden body with a 2 finger white head.  Orange peel, funk JP style, some woodiness, dry wood, farmhouse.  Easy on the palate with a tart finish and no etoh.  eh.

Brilliant golden pour with gorgeous and frothy white head, decent retention.  Funked out nose with a citrus zest and quiet spice undertones for aromas.  A spiced-citrus dryness marks a  pronounced souring kick which really cleans out the palate.  There are also yeasty barnyard element which quietly echoes towards the back.

12oz. bottle.  Enticing aroma, with a full spectrum of yeast characteristics, spice and citrus, featuring notes of lemon, pear, orange peel, wheaty grain, vanilla and flowers, while there is also farmhouse, dough, cobwebs, clove, straw and plenty of tartness to be found.  Cloudy light golden amber color with a lasting, fine head and a dusting of sediment.  Flavor profile is tart, citric and fruity to start, becoming a bit more malty, sweet, woody and spicy, and finishing with a gentle burst of sourness, light bitterness and coriander, managing to dry out considerably and retain that edge of yeast funkiness as it goes.  Lightly acidic, thin and relatively low in effervescence with a light body as well.  I think this is my new favorite Wit, the yeast character just giving that extra refreshing and "moreish" quality to an already easygoing, summery style.  Its a slightly older bottle, too, from what I understand, but I certainly couldnt tell.  Thanks to csbosox for this!

A golden with with a creamy white lacing head. Fantastic Brett in aroma, pungent, with lemon and cloves notes. Wow! In mout, a refreshing liquid with light banana malt, light Brett, a bit of lemon. This is an excellent example of the wit! Superbly balanced. Bieropholie import, tasted around May 2007.
Very nice wit. A whiff of tartness in the nose is followed up on the tongue. Very refreshing.

Bottled. Poured cloudy gold, with a white, bubbly head. Very bubbly appearance. Nose was citrus (lemon) and yeast. Flavor was Lemongrass, yeast, orange peel, perhaps a bit of coriander, though not as pronounced as some Wits. Finish was dry, tart, and refreshing.

Bottle: Pours a hazy yellow with a bubbly/strong white head. Fresh and bright aroma with a lemony acidity, a touch of oak and a hint of coriander spice. An inviting aroma. Has a crisp and cleansing mouthfeel. Very quenching, with a light acidity overall. Strong lemon presence upfront followed by mild touch of coriander. It has a bone dryness, making it even more drinkable. The aftertaste has apparent wheat character. The flavor is less complex than the aroma suggests, but its crisp and refreshing. Great Spring/Summer beer.
12oz bottle: Cloudy yellow in color, BIG head... Aroma is lemon and citrus fruit.  Taste is a crisp and refreshing, sour lemon in flavor. Low carbonation and easy to drink. Good summer brew.

I know its different...but I liked it.  Hoegaarden like in color and texture.  Translucent lemon in color with a nice 2-fingered head.  Aroma is earthy, with hints of coriander, citrus, and brett.  Taste is refreshing and sour.  Not a huge fan of the style but I can imagine enjoying this on a hot AZ summer day.

750 ml bottle shared with Ben (thanks!), served cool in a Petrus goblet (tulip?). JN06/08.
App.:  Clear golden, fair white meringue.
  
Aroma:  Minerals, light funk (definitely barnyard), light lemon and coriander, light bitter greens.
  
Palate:  Medium-ish body, moderate effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much like the nose  restrained citrus, coriander and funk; minerals; slightly tart, a touch of bitterness, leaves a bit of bitter greens behind.

Lovely, light and refreshing; a great thirst quencher.

Bottle (750ml). Now this is a great beer. Pours with a cloudy yellow golden color and a medium head. Nice aromas of funkiness, lemon and a bit of mustiness. Flavors are more of a biere de garde style, with lost of funkiness, citrus and a bit of pepper. It lacks the coriander and ornagne peel flavor of typical American wits. The oak from barrel aging seems to shine thorugh but it is subtle and perhaps it is my imagination. Very complex body, smooth and medium thickness. A master piece as far as wits are concerned

12 oz. bottle. Powerful, nice aroma with farmhouse ale qualities. Sour, citrusy smell features apple juice, lemon, and orange scents. Surprisingly, there is also a touch of smokiness in the aroma. Pours a sparkling, bright gold with an orange tint. Many bubbles. The liquid is mostly clear with a touch of haze. Large amount of fluffy, uneven, near-white head. Produces thick lacing. I came close to giving this a 5 for the appearance. Sour taste; more of a lemony, citrus sourness than a white wine or vinegar effect. Light Belgian-style candy sugar flavor. Subtle but complex taste. Some boozy dryness in the finish. Medium body. Soft, smooth, frothy, and lively in the palate. Easy to drink. Calabaza Blanca is quite enjoyable and better than I expected. I really liked this beer at first, but my enthusiasm gradually cooled as I drank it.
Bottle. Pale amber beer with a nice off-white head. LIght orange, yeast, brett aroma. Orange, yeast, brett, wheat flavors. Medium-light body - easy drinking. Lingering wheat, orange, and yeast.

Bottled, poured in a dimpled mug.  The color of JPCB is a washed out light yellow.  It has a large creamy head that doesnt leave a lot of lacing.  The aroma is tart with a hint of wood and cooked yellow hominey.  This is a wonderfully refreshing beer with just the right amount of citrus tart balanced with a surprising smoothness.  There is a lambic-like taste that makes me think of wild yeast.  The finish is quick and dry.  This is an excellent Jolly Pumpkin beer and one of my favorite wits.

"Old" bottle with oval label:  Tart, funky and very refreshing.  There was tons of carbonation in this bottle.  Even with age, this was not the most complex beer but it was very enjoyable due to the wonderful balance and freshness.

Meh.  Nose and taste are the same...loads and loads of yeat, a bit of citrus and maybe some berry.

Refreshing enough but definitely something not worth trying again  There are far better whites out there than this one.

Pours a clear yellow color with medium sized fluffy head that fades quickly.  Aroma is all up in your face with the wild yeast.  Its to the point where thats all I could smell, everything else took a backseat to this.    Taste is interesting.  I really have a hard time finding anything but the wild freakin yeast.  Oh wait...found it.  There is some light citrus and a bit of spice in the very fringes of the finish on this puppy.  Im surprised I didnt have to puke some up to coat the tongue once more to see if there was anything else except wild yeast.    Strange as it seems, take any JP beer, mix it up with some Lindemans Cuvee Rene, and toss in some orange peel and you got this.  Dont get me wrong, its not bad, it just disappoints me as I was expecting something really stellar with this one.  Finish is quite dry and tart and carbonation is moderate.  Again, its not bad, just not something I would pick up at $3.50 a bottle.  Instead, Id rather buy a 6 pack of Hoegaarden, somehow cause it to have a yeast infection and chase it with some Monistat 7.  Prost!

Pours a hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, citrus and a little yeasty funk. Flavor of wheat and wild yeasts, a little funk, citrus, spices with lots of carbonation. Interesting brew.

Never had a tart witbier beer like this one before.  Definitely a thirst quenching beer.   Wouldnt want to start drinking this on a hot summer day - I would down a six pack in no time and this isnt cheap stuff.  Some nice light spice in aroma and taste.  Would I buy it again?  Maybe, but there are other excellent Witbiers just as tasty and at a more reasonable price.

Cloudy pale yellow with a bunch of tiny brown particles released at the end of the pour. Sour apple, sour grape aroma. Woody sour, puckering tartness, citrus and spice flavour are dominated by the overall sourness, but this still comes across as light, zesty, and refreshing.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Pours a golden yellow with a thick, but quickly disappearing white head.  Tastes really sweet, maybe a little too much.  Definitely some orange and other citrusy flavors.  Very nice dry finish.  Pretty decent, but I was expecting more at that price.  The bottle looks cool though.

Pours an opaque gold color with a thick, yet quick to disappear, whitish head.  Aroma is full of wheat, orange, funk (a bit too much, or else something had gone slightly wrong) and feet...not much spice to speak of.  The flavor was much better than the aroma...lots of citrus (tons of lemon, and some orange), wheat, yeast, and a nice acidic funk to back things up.  Any spice, including coriander, takes a backseat in this brew, as it doesnt stand out as it does in most Wits.  Good on the palate...finishes very dry (would compare to a white wine) and keeps you coming back for more.  I would pick this one up again, despite the odd aroma, so I would say this is a pretty good beer, though definitely off the beaten path for the style.

Whats this?  A commonly available JP beer I havent rated?  Well, better late than never - hazy golden, fizzy beer, with a quickly dissipating head - the aroma has the standard JP funkiness to it, that seems to overpower the more subtle nuances (no big deal, though, since I enjoy their yeast), but some of the spices come through a little bit - tingly carbonation in the mouth - the light tartness and earthy funk that is common to their beers doesnt overpower in the flavor like it does in some others - there is a nice combination and lemon/citrus acidity, soft wheaty flavors, and light leathery funk - the spicy character the style usually brings is not very present, but the lively, crisp tartness that replaces it makes up for it, and makes the beer more like a berliner weisse than a wit - not their best offering, but a nice refreshing brew.

Bottle from Raleigh WBF.  My least favorite of their offering, perhaps because the wheat overshadowed the yeast, and I do like the funky wild yeasts they use.  Lemony/citrusy with some spices, but not over the top.  A very nice white.

750. Beer is hazy, light pale gold with a large, frothy, white, diminishing head. Seagulls of lace on the glass.The aroma is malty with a light note of toasted grain; Hoppy with a moderate note of lemon zest, light note of pine resin; Yeasty with a light note of sharp band-aid; Trace of orange zest, light coriander and white pepper.The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, trace bitter with a longish, lightly acidic, trace sweet finish.The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

From NEPA case split on 4-25-08 from Kevin. Elegant white with a nice sour leathery backbone and an amped up coriander spice content (to the point I expected to see some floating around). There is a floral ginger quality here but otherwise it doesnt get any more complex. Highly carbonated and dry like cider but not thick or creamy.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2012 750ml from Sams, Durham. Funky butt? Funky wit!!! Now this is what Im talking about. Way to take a pretty meh style - at least as far as the usual offerings, either too watery or too cloyingly sweet - and give some depth and serious quirkiness without compromising style. A gorgeous pour with a big silky head, the aroma is suggestive to say the least. Sure the usual ingredients (listed in the commercial description) are there, but you get a nice funk element in there - not JP barnyard dank but a blend of dry brett  and over the hill melon/orange. Theres slightly more sharpness in the taste, but the funky elements are the strongest, and I think thats a very good thing. I still wont drop this kind of coin for a wit too often, but this is probably the best Ive had.
Bottle. Pours a sparkling bright golden color. Some floaties. Spicy nose. Carbonated bubbles. Crisp tasting with Jolly Pumpkin funk & Tartness. Wit spiciness of citrus & coriander. Good beer

12oz Bottle thanks to 17th floor. Pours a hazy pale orange yellow color with decent white head. Some medium yeasties at the bottom of the glass. Minimal spotty lacing. Aroma is somewhat funky yeast, mild bandaid, tart fruit, some grape. Flavor is tart and somewhat grapey, mild earthy hop bitterness, yeast flavors of horse blanket and mild bandaid. Body is crisp and refreshing with a nice moderate to mild acidity. Finishes rather dry with some wood notes coming forward.

12oz bottle with a little age. Pours a slightly hazy golden with a slight white head that quickly fades to a slight ring around the edge, leaving some lacing. Light JP tart funk on the nose. Really tastes like a toned down Luciernaga. Sour tart upfront, corriander drys out the finish. Leaves a crisp dry mouth at the end. This is quite good, want to try this fresh too.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2009 [4.15.08] Pours a hazy light yellow with some big bubbles with a foamy white head.  Aroma of wild yeast, very sour, tart, oak and some coriander.  Very tart /sour flavor, I like that the oak is subtle and is not overly waxy or adds too much vanilla.  Yummy sourness.  Citrus, apples and a touch of pepper.  Crisp and very clean palate.  Delicious.  8.4.9.5.17

[rerated - 6.18.09 - 12oz bottle from early 08]  I almost couldnt bring myself to open this seeing as it was the last Jolly Pumpkin 6-pack on the shelves.  If I had realized they were discontinued I would have stocked up as it was way cheaper than the big bottles.  What a fantastic beer this is and is even better after a year+ of aging, delightfully light and probably the most refreshing beer on the planet, so crisp and playfully tart.  Definitely one to be had on a clean palate as its delicacy could really get looked over if one were not careful.

This drinks like a great white wine or champagne under bottle conditioning. The coriander lasts throughout yet grabs the tart taste that only the trappists can follow.  It would be complementary to a french fondue feast or a belgium brew taste. Jolly has softened my heart and opened my palate to this fulfilling ale. This style isnt the greatest with my hoppy needs but I know a good beer when I drink one.

[bottle] Perhaps I got a bad bottle, because many of the other ratings claim characteristics that were absolutely not present in my bottle. There was very little carbonation, it tasted watered down, and the finish wasnt dry in the least. Im not saying it was a bad beer, the sourness was a pleasant surprise and I know what the brewery was getting at, but it just wasnt quite reproduced in the bottle I was served. I will have to revisit this one.

Slightly hazy yellow body.  Aroma is lightly sour and bretty.  The flavor is also slightly sour, a bit funky, followed by some wit sweetness and spice.  The finish becomes sour again, but only faintly.  Overall refreshing and delicate.

Bottle:  Poured a bright yellow with a thick white head.  The aroma was orange and spicey lemons.  The flavor was that of tart apples and lemons with the coriander showing up near the end.  Overall, a wonderfully balanced beer, one that Im currently searching for more of.

A pure light gold body with a HUGE white head. A lightly spicey aroma... almost maranara like.  Taste is very carbonated, nice spices, some light lemon evident.  Ending is lightly tart, quite tasty though.
750ml bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Florida). Pours clear yellow with a thick bright white head. Aroma: strong citrus overtones. Flavor: citrus, spice, coriander. Dry finish.
Sour and lemony. Head vanishes quickly. It is very interesting and spicy. I like all the stuff floating around in it
Straw yellow that is somewhat thick, with bright white head.  Nose of lemon and spice.  flavor is very citric that sours out to a full on lemon finish.  A lot of carbination in this one.

Jolly Pumpkin Calabaza Blanca is a very original take on a Belgiam White. The color is a very nice unfined light amber with a quickly disappearing head. The aroma is a little more sour and tart than the traditional Witbier. The addition of ginger to this beer covers the natural corriander spice found in this type of beer. While I was a little intimidated by the different taste at first, I quickly started to like this beer a lot.

12 oz. bottle courtesy Naka.  Pours a hazy straw yellow with golden hues.  Thin white head, foamy and rimming.  Nose is funky lemon with notes of spice.  Bready start leading into a mild Brett funk with some spice that fades into a strong citric finish that leaves a bit of a sour/tart after.  Mouthfeel is nice, with the carbonation only adding to a rather full, viscous experience.  Another great offering from whats becoming to be one of my favorite breweries.  Starting to love the funk.

Pours a hazy golden straw color.  A small white head that dissipated quickly.  Has the funky barnyard citrus sauerkraut nose.  A dry sour flavor that has some grain underneath.  Definitely some lemon citrus flavors and coriander.  There is a slight sweetness, but it is very faint.  Pretty par for the course from J.P.  The spicy farmhouse style that they do very well.  Lots of carbonation that gives it a pretty decent body.   Not as good as a lot of other J.P. brews that Ive had, but very drinkable.

Poured into a standard pint glass. Very pale straw colour- similar to your std macro lager, but with a three finger head. Smell- citrus, woody brett. Taste- loads of citrus fruit, grainy and medium spice. Finishes really clean with snappy tartnes. The oak and brett are there, but not in your face. Medium carbonation, combined with the light body makes a thirst quenching beer. The least complex JP beer Ive tried to date, but a nice drinker.
Pours hazy yellow with a very white head and lots of sediment.  Aroma is citrus and what I can only describe as vinegar.  Goes down smooth with a sour citrus finish.

Big bottle pours hazy pale amber with a bright white head and decent lace.  The aroma is wet leather, spicy, and yeasty.  The flavor starts out wit like, but then morphs into a sour bracing finish that reminds me of something like lambic.  Perhaps it is the orange peel and coriander, but I think this one is flat out brett.  We have some serious wild yeast in this.  I have one of the older bottles with the non-round lables.  Im wondering if this was really supposed to be this sour?  Infection?  No, I think this one is OK.  I guess what really matters is if it tastes good.  Not bad at all.

750 ml. bottle,  this should be called calabaza amargo , this reminds me of a nice sour ale more than a wit, cloudy yellow color and nice fluffy head, some banana and sour lemon on the nose and then a big sour citrus ale , this is very nice
Superb White.  Hazy highly carbonated pale yellow ale.  Very citrus nose.  Bubbles that stay alive with orange taste.

Bottle. Somewhat hazy orange-yellow pour with a fizzy...somewhat creamy white head. Aroma of mild citrus rind/zest, apple skin, light pepper, yeast, and a bit of spice. Flavors of apple, citrus zest, coriander, yeast, dry malt, pepper, and a hint of funk. Light body with a lively carbonation...tart/juicy with a malty/dry/tart finish. Nice! This might be a good session brew for when it warms up, especially now that it comes in sixers!

12 oz bottle.  Clear glistening gold with a cap of white foam.  Pretty.  Nose is lemon and yeast fading to pear and green apple.  Crisp and juicy with wheaty creaminess.  Taste is pear nectar, lemon peel and coriander with pith.  Simple but highly drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2014 750mL bottle. thanks to Pwn3d. Pours a light, cloudy orange with little white head. The aroma is some tart and citrus. The taste is light overall - orange, citrus, coriander, tart, and wheat. I thought this little billy was pretty solid. One of my favorites.

Medium bodied, well carbonated. Tart lemon and wheat flavor with some spices. Lightly bitter, lingering finish. Good taste, but not especially interesting. Not an ordinary witbier, but not my favorite either.
Poured transparent with a white head. Citrus and spice to the nose. Not much flavor except citrus. Not impressed at all.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: this beer is amazing, truly unique.  pours a golden color with a big ole lacy head.  aromas and notes of citrus fruit, grass, honeysuckle.  does a nice earthy, yeasty, sour turn in the mouth.  this beer is complex and intriguing, multiple food pairings are possible.

Another good Belgian White beer that I like.  Pours slightly cloudy and straw colored.  Thin white head that leaves a little lacing.  Aroma is heavily yeasty...like a steamed hot dog bun!  There is also a hint of citrus.  Bright and carbonated on the palate.  The flavor is spicy and smooth at the same time.  Very tart entrance with lemon rind notes leads to a dry, smooth finish.  A pretty refreshing beer.
pours with a big wet head and settles into a light lace.  smells like it tastes, briny and rough with a sharp almost Flemish sour finish.  reminds me of fortified wine in some ways.
Pours a clear straw color with a foamy white head.  Yeasty nose with lemon rind and spice.  Tastes like a tart lemon rind with a bit of bret.  Finishes clean, I like this beer.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2008 Pours a light gold with a medium chunky head and some beautiful lacing.  Aromas of spice and citrus, on the tart side.  Flavor of lemons and grain, again slightly tart.  Very good.

From unclemattie via trade.  The pour was turbid and yellow, a bit of rapidly rising foam popped out right before I poured it.  The head was ample, white and fizzy on the pour but settle into a nice creamy and rocky mound.  Decent lacing.  The aroma was light funk blanketed over pepper, lemon and orange.  Slightly yeasty.  The flavor was mainly sour citrus fruits of lemon and some unripe orange tartness.  Also noted were light amounts of bretty funk, grass and earth.  Active carbonation and relatively light mouthfeel.  The finish was dry and the beer was easy to drink.  Thanks again Matt!

Inspiring - it hits the nose with aromas of a dying fall and a young hopeful winter. The palate has liveliness and acidity, while the aromas hint of funky squash and rotting orange (brilliantly) , the palate is fresh citrus and apples.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in a shaker.  This witbier poured a hazy golden with a two-finger thick head of fizzy white foam that settled a bit and lasted throughout most of the glass.  A small amount of faint lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of citrus, lemongrass,  spicy yeast esthers, bread, and hay.  The flavor included tart lemon, light corriander, bread, and grass.  Excellent flavor for the style.  The mouthfeel was light-bodied and crisp with moderate to high carbonation.  Very refreshing and insanely drinkable!

Bottle from Liquid Solutions. Aroma of tart, lemony citrus. Hazy, grey tinged golden color with a respectable fine bubble white head. Thin to medium body with fizzy carbonation. Flavor starts a bit funky, sour and citric. Orange peel and coriander likely. The overall effect has me thinking something towards gueze or lambic. Finish is definitely dry and suggestive of the farm. Its a very interesting and impressive drink.

12 oz bottle from Sams no date on the bottle was purchased 1/08.  I was hoping to grab a few of these before the price jump.  Golden yellow color with a tall off white head.  Tart nose.  Barnyard, hay, grain, lemon, yeast.  Lightly funky.  It really reminded me of the lambic fest at Delilahs.  The grain, hay, and funk was similar to a gueze.  Mouthfeel is a little watery.  Grain, orange peel, lemon, hay, barnyard, oaky earthiness.  These flavors blend together well with an underlying yeast/wheat flavor and a tart and crisp finish.  Other than being a little watery, this is really solid.

Aroma is all coriander. Flavor is sour apple, citruc zest, wet grass, orange. Pretty sour but not a bombardment of it. Light and easy to drink. Reminds me of champagne looking into the glass. Nice beer.

Bottle like image shown.  Light hazy off-gold. Nose is light lemon and banana.  Mouth is well carbonated, very spritzer - reminds me of a Unibroue in that regard.   Flavor is lemon, orange peel, with sparingly small amounts of coriander.  Very tart which lingers, perhaps a bit too tart for my liking.  This has some lambic characteristics.  Incredibly balanced, all the characteristics of this beer work together to put a smile on your face.  I would suggest splitting this with your best mate.. might be too sour to kill the bottle on your own.

Light bright aroma with light pickle juice qualities.  Golden yellow with a thin white head.  Slightly malty saltiness and pickled flavors.  Some spiciness, some citrus.  Fairly dry on the finish. Tart.

Clear yellow pour with a small white head.  Aroma of lemon, sour apple, spice, orange zest, and slightly peppery.  Peppery flavor with lots of zesty citrus on the finish.  Dry sour apple note lingering after the swallow.  Thin body with lots of carbonation.

750 ml bottle thanks to a considerate friend with great luck at picking beers. Pours a clear honey/gold color with a large frothy whtie head. Nice funky aroma with notes of wood, of course, slight citrus and maybe a hint of grass. Light bodied with light carbonation that is very refreshing. Funky flavor with notes of old wood, lemons, yeast and spice. Funny I once dated a girl that was nicknamed the Jolly Pumpkin, not quite sure why but she did have a very round head and smiled a lot....hmm??

Med-pale, slightly hazy yellow, w/ a decent off-white head. Aroma: Orange, vinegar, light nail polish. Taste: fairly acidic lemon, little bit of sweat. Mouthfeel is just right, but strength of taste could be greater.

Clear, clean yellow/gold with some green toward the edges.  Tart aroma reminds me of lambics, expecting dry flavors.  Very light and crisp, not too dry at all.  Quite a lot of sediment on the bottom.......chunky bits fall slowly to the bottom of the glass once lifted out of the bottle and add some haze.  Beer gets a bit sweeter too, but not by much.  Lemon citrus and vinegar remains, all flavors are delicate and short lasting.
Aroma is spiced.. i think i may smell pickles? (weird i know) Golden, unfiltered color, light head. A lot of sediment. Flavor of sweet fruits. Interesting flavors.
750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy golden yellow with a medium sized white head.  Aroma of funk, sour apple, lemon and yeast.  Taste of spicy sour apple and lemon with a funk flavored finish.  Interesting.

Light and clean.  Some green apple and lemon, and a clean dryness to it.  Slightly sour.  This is completely different from the last bottle I remember of this stuff, but much better.  Despite not being a gucher, as I expected, it may be a little over carbonated.  Also may be overattenuated, as the malt character it lacking.  I seem to really be getting nothing but the sour lemon flavor and a little acetylaldehyde.  Tastes OK, but really nothing like a witbier at all, and lacking in complexity.  Points also taken off for inconsistency.  Ive been much more impressed with JPs other beers.
Light hazy golden yellow pour with a nice finger sized frothy white head.  A nice funky sour smell with some citrus notes.  A nice tartness with a little bit of orange.

On cask at Churchills.  Ivan gratiously gave me a sample. I love cask.  Casky, cask, cask.  A hint of sour.  Some corriander in the aroma.  Summer saison flavor. Light cloudy yellow color with huge foamy cascading cask head.  A bit of nice yeasty aroma.  Super dangerously easy to drink.
this  slightly sour, dry, tanniny treat pours super bubbly and is a very nice drink...

Bottle: This is extremely light in color, golden orange, with an active fizz but little head retention.  The aroma is citrusy and delicately spiced.  That spiciness comes otu a lot bigger once it hits the tongue ... thick with corriander and earthy herbiness, riding on a light ripple of fruitiness underneath.  (#3291, 1/13/2008)

12oz Bottle

Recieved this bottle from my RB Secret Santa, thanks Melvin. Calabaza Blanca turned out to be yet another Jolly Pumpkin gusher. Pours an opaque, hazy straw golden. Streams of carbonation chase each other to the small crown of white head that formed on the pour. Leaves a patch of lace here and there.

Smell has a little bit of that dusty funkiness to it. A solid dose of tangy wheat shows itself below the dustiness. Not much in the way of orange peel but there is a pinch of coriander. The aroma, unfortunately, doesnt stand out much.

Flavor follows the nose. Some wheat twang and a little of the funkiness but all characteristics seem really dumbed down. Not a lot of complexity or flavor. Im usually not a big fan of wits the way it is but this one leaves things to be desired.

The mouthfeel is pretty average. The problem is there is too much carbonation which makes this beer move through entirely too fast. Very prickly but no body with the high carbonation.

This beer goes down about like an ice cold macro. Non-offensive and easy to drink but not something I wouldnt waste my time drinking more than one.

Ive always passed by this beer because Im usually not in the mood for a wit. Now that Ive had the opportunity to give it a try Im glad I have passed it by. There are much better wits out there and for much better prices. Calabaza Blanca is a chink in Jolly Pumpkins armor.

12/30/07

Pours a cloudy, glowing yellow-gold body with a small, fizzy white head.  The foam eventually settles to a patchy film, leaving minimal spotty lacing in its wake.  The aroma is a very light and crisp lemony citrus profile, almost like an unsweetened lemonade.  This is without a doubt the least funky of the Jolly Pumpkin brews.  The flavor is again light and crisp, with dry, lightly sweetened lemon, coriander, and mild JP funk comprising the bulk of things.  Light bodied, though substantial enough for the style.  A dry palate and a low ABV begs for the next sip, causing this one to go down very quickly.  Id reach for this interesting, warm weather brew over a Wittekerke any day of the week.

Pours a very clear, pale straw - odd. Tight egg-white head. Light creamy spice (vanilla) & marshmallow aroma. Soft, American-style wit. Sweet, corn-syrup, weak & watery. Body is creamy with good carbonation, but on the whole is too thin to be engaging. Meh.

Poured a clear golden color into the weizen glass with an inch of thin, bubbly head.  There was a small amount of lacing and hundreds of tiny bubbles releasing from the bottom of the glass, floating to the top.  Opening the bottle sent notes of sour apples, wheat, pepper and spice into the air.  A flavorful, drinkable beer with some sour notes and some citrus flavors.  A funky, tart finish was rather enjoyable.  A delightful beer.

Bottle from Crown #15, in Fishers, IN. Pours a hazy straw with a huge, fluffy, meringue-like, white head that leaves behind wispy lace as it descends. The nose is a round wheat body with a lightly "dusty" note, mild coriander and lesser notes of both orange and wood. Light-bodied and quite effervescent the mouthfeel finishes with a sour, dry and somewhat woody finish. Nice tart and sour wheat front the flavor with lighter notes of citrus and coriander in support. My buddy, who likes Hoegaarden and other micro-wits, absolutely hated this beer. I thought the sour tartness added to its intrigue. To each his own. That just meant more for me. :)
Another great beer from Jolly Pumpkin.  The spices compliment the spicy tang from the oak barrels.  The bubbles play along the roof of your mouth like champagne.   Very nice and drinkable.
Bottle: Great beer.  Pours a pale yellow with a large head.  Aroma of fruit (apple+).  Almost like a tart heifeweizen.  Very good.

750ml bottle
Pours cloudy gold with a nice white head that leaves significant lacing.  Streaming bubbles throughout.  Citrus overwhelms the nose.  Taste is tart, dry orange.  Very nice.

750 ml bottle.  The first pour is crystal clear brilliant gold with an uneven white head.  Its early afternoon and the sun is streaming into my family room.  When I hold my glass up into the sun, this beer, with its many carbonation bubbles, seems to illuminate.  Very nice aroma of lemons, oranges and a bit of coriander.  The flavor is sour, but not excessively so, with more lemon than orange and a bit of spice as well.  Appropriately light mouthfeel.  Very good.

Jolly pumpkin you are officially on notice. This is the second beer from you that I have poured down the drain! Pours an ugly yellow color with a foamy head that shrinks quickly. Smells of spices and wheat. However there is some sort of mystery spice used by jolly pumpkin (also in your bam biere) that is DISGUSTING. Tastes of some nasty funky spice and there is yeast all over in the beer. Nasty taste to thanks.

I was expecting so much more out of this one.  I love almost all their stuff and was expecting the same out of the Calabaza.  It is dark and spicy as I had hoped but I was expecting something more sour, in a good way.  Dont get me wrong, it is quite enjoyable, but I had hoped for much more.

750 mL champagne bottle.  Pours a light golden color with a foamy white head and some light lacing on the sides of the glass.  Aroma is very slightly sour, with citrus and that regular white ale spiced smell underneath.  Taste is pretty tart, very refreshing and citrusy.  Im kind of upset that I waited so long to try this... Im generally not a fan of Jolly Pumpkin or white ales, but this is really the best of both worlds.  Yum.

Old 750ml bottle with the oval labels.  Dont know the date.  Pours surprisingly clear (until the gunk on the bottom is poured in), golden with a very active fluffy white head.  Looks like champagne.  Aroma is surprisingly subdued and mild.  I thought a lot more funk would be present.  Light biscuitiness, a little tartness, no spices.  Some wheat and clove but barely.  No funkiness in sight.  Taste is thin, tart, light bodied, tingly.  Very dry.  Lots of carbonation.  This is all right but not one of Jolly Pumpkins better beers.  After having an aged version of La Roja that blew my mind I had high hopes for this one and was let down.  Will have to try it fresh some time.

We used this to celebrate the Cowboys come from behind victory yesterday.  Poured a average white head.  Aroma of orange and spices.  Good amount of spices and lemon flavor.  Got alittle sour as it warmed.

Fairly clear straw gold with a small head and lots of carbonation. Strong and acidic yeast in the nose with some lemon citrus there. Damp hay/straw there as well. The flavor is fairly spicy with a sweeter version of the lemon citrus coming out. The yeast and straw notes are there as well. Not as strong as the nose. Nice and light mouthfeel. Finishes off with a touch of spicy citrus.

bottle at ds.  pours a mostly clear honey yellow, with little yeasty floaters here and there.  big white head that fades but sticks around as a film, and leaves a bit of lacing.  strong smell of lemon, some garden aromas, and a good bit of indescribable funk hanging around.  taste is a good orange and lemon citrus flavor, with a musty vegetable note.  a bit of spiciness comes out at the edges.  strange and complex, and good.  finish is a light sourness, with a tiny bit of sweetness, and light to moderate hoppy bitterness.  creamy, silky mouthfeel.  good stuff.

Beershine notes that traditional Eastern medicine recommends all the five flavors (sweet, sour, salty, spicy, and bitter) be in a meal. They are all in this beer but for me it clashes. Acidic sourness dominates like an Flemish sour ale. Coriander, cloves, orange and lemon peel, yeasty barnyard hay thing. Bottle fermented yeast is overkill. It may be good for the style but bottom line is I do not care for the style.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2009 ++++ Re Rate 26 May 2009 ++++
750 ml bottle purchased at Lukas in Kansas City, Missouri. Batch 285 sticker on back of bottle (Brewed: 2/29/08, To Oak: 3/05/08, Bottled: 4/02/08). Pour is hazed darker yellow with some floaties. Two inch white head is fizzy and noisy, with visible carbonation. Patchy lacing. Aroma of citric lemon tart and sour. Nice wheat body element, slight spicy yeastiness. Nice bright nose. Taste is bright citric wheat, prickly tart - puckering sour orange, lemon and limes. Nice fresh earthiness behind that. The funky JP yeast is present in the finish, adding complexity. Palate is thin to medium, dryish, slick, lots of carbonation. This was crisp, refreshing and really easy to drink. (7,4,8,5,16 - 4.0)

++++ Original Rating 20 Nov 2007 ++++
750ml bottle from Beertopia in Omaha, NE. Pour is clear golden with a ton of carbonation bubbles. A big fluffy white head of 3 inches settles down to about 1/2 inch and remains. Aroma of citrus, wheat, yeast, Belgian sugar sweetness, and only a hint of sour funk. Taste is more pronounced with the barnyard sour funk, though it is nicely blended with the lemon citrus freshness, and beautifully constructed palate. Crazy drinkable. This beer was tremendous with the spicy Italian sandwich I was eating. Nice work JP. (7,4,8,4,15 - 3.8)

12 oz bottle- Pours a cloudy golden color w/a good size foamy white head & some yeast floaters. Sweet aroma of wheat & grass. Flavors of lemon, wheat, bread dough, cane sugar & colander. Very fresh, smooth, easy drinking brew. This beer is everything a Belgian Whitbier should be: smooth, refreshing, easy drinking, & enjoyable. One of the best samples of this style. Long dry finish.

75cl bottle. Hazy gold color with a mountainous head . Great aromas of barnyard, hay, old leather, citrus, and spices, wood. Medium body with flavors of coriander, zesty lemons, and JPs signature barnyard and wood . Finishes with a spicy herbal burp. These people know how to make a great beer.10/28/07
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: As the beer spills from the 12-ounce bottle, the color is foggy yellow with a perfect white hue, head is a huge pile of cotton to crown the body, as it slowly dematerializes, and the lacing forms a white curtain to drape the glass. Nose has a rich bread dough aroma, aromatic spices, coriander, cloves and a nice orange peel hint, to accompany the crispness. Start is sweet with grain and spices, a bit of tartness at the back, top is light to medium. Finish has a prickly acidity, sweet with a touchy of hop spiciness, quite dry aftertaste lingers long, a fine representative to the style.

Poured a light golden color with a thin diminishing white head.  Smelled of coriander, citrus, and belgian candi sugar.  Taste was much the same, nicely balanced and light.  Ever so slight sour finish.

Aroma:  Light horseblanket brett, some fruitiness, and some pils malt.

Appearance:  Pale yellow, good head retention, fluffy white head.  Slightly cloudly.

Flavor:  Not much here, except for Brett character.  Not much a wit character otherwise.  Not much spiciness, the only character really comes from the Brett.  Not bad, but nothing outstanding.  Dry finish.

Palate:  Dry, good for style.

Overall:  Nice beer, but one-dimensional.  Needs more of a wit character along with the already present Brett ferment.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2011 All the five flavors (sweet, sour, salty, spicy, and bitter) are present in this finely crafted witbier and the only one Ive ever raved about. Jolly Pumpkins is an extraordinary execution of this style. Other brewers have tended more toward the sweet side of the flavor spectrum or worse--avoided flavor altogether to produce a beer that looks better than it tastes. Not so with the Calabaza Blanca! Its crazy combination of flavors makes this a beer to come back to. Delicious and nutritious. According to Eastern medicine, all five flavors should be present in every healthy meal--and apparently it works for beer too....OK I came back to it at the Whole Foods taproom in Santa Rosa. Is witbier looking hazy luminescent tight white cap, aroma is clean Brett and the juicy fruit flavors are peach plus Brett plus barrel dryness great balance light white fruit and eggshells and loquat skin and pear and star fruit. more like 4-7-3-8-16 or 4-7-4-8-16 but the original rating stands for now...

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2013 750ml, square label.  Huge funky nose of brett, floral notes, soap, wheat and hay.  Instantly tart and sour on the tongue, with lemon, sour and very dry woody wheat and hay, and a moderate presence of brett, showing up more as a prickly tart/sourness than a true funkiness.  Finishes with lingering lemon juice and whisky and gin flavors.  Interesting and unique.

Bottle.  Hazy yellow color/ Nice wheat aroma with a big white head.  Taste a little sour and the spices really dont come through as much as  I would like.   I am not sure if the price justifies the product, but it is still a really good Witbier.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 10/13/2007:  Jolly Pumpkin Calabaza Blanca pours a cloudy golden yellow color with a moderate amount of carbonation.  The white head is quite large and shapely with stiff peaks (reminds me of whipped egg whites).  It lasts from the initial pour all the way through the last sip and leaves foamy lacing on the glass.  The aroma is a bit sour with some woodiness present.  It is very inviting.  At first the sourness of the Brett and the dry oaky flavor from the barrel jump out, but then the yummy funkiness melds into the other flavors with each subsequent taste.  Some of the delicate underlying citrus and spicy qualities of the Wit beer can then be found.  The coriander complements the tartness nicely and really cuts through as the beer warms up some.  This beer has a medium-light body and is lively on the palate.  This is a really good and unique White Ale.  Jolly Pumpkin makes great beer and even though the 750 mL bottles are cool, I hope that they start to offer their other beers in 12 ounce bottles like this one...
12 fl. oz. bottle (5.9% Alc. by Vol.) from Firemoose15.  Thanks Mel!  Rating #381 for this beer...  Rating:  7  4  8  3  15 = 3.7.
______________________________

5/27/2008:  Calabaza Blanca Artisan White Ale has a hazy/cloudy pale golden color.  There is a high level of carbonation that crates a large, pillowing, and completely lasting white to off-white head.  The aroma is lightly fruity and tart.  A lemony acidity combines with some delicate apple, pear, spice, and yeast.  The flavor is a little tart like citrus/lemon pithe and slightly sour and funky.  It is really quite refreshing and exciting on the palate.  The spice is very subtle and the finish as somewhat dry.  The beer is light and crisp on the palate and has a smooth texture.  This is such a great beer and perfect for both who are interesting in adventuring into the world of sour beers as it is a good cross-over/starter beer for that!  I think I prefe this older, lower alcohol version in the larger bottle over the newer, stronger version in the 12 ounce bottles.  It seems to be more balanced...
750 ml bottle (4.8% alc/vol) with oval label and a blue cap from Rivers Bend Wine and Spirits ($6.99+tax) in Maineville, Ohio.  Rating:  7  4  8  3  16 = 3.8.

750 ml bottle, from Holiday Wine Cellars.  This bottle turned into a gushing fountain just after I opened it, emptying approximately 1/3 of the contents onto my kitchen counter and into my sink before I could get a glass under it.  Maybe Im just grumpy tonight, but this pisses me off.  Anyway, the remaining liquid was a slightly hazy golden color with a huge fluffy white head.  Aroma of sour apples, yeast, clove lemon and a bit of funk.  Flavor is like a tart cider just turning to vinegar, with sourdough and yeast, bitter herbs, light spice and orange zest.  Light body with gently fizzy carbonation.  Im deducting a couple of tenths from the overall for the gushing surprise upon popping the cap.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Liquor Loft - 12 oz bottle. Medium golden, murky, with a long lasting sticky snow white head. Lemon and vinegary aroma with hints of coriander. Crisp, fresh flavor which leans heavily to the sour side of the spectrum.  Similar flavor accents find their way from the aroma to the taste buds. Hints of sour cherries, vinegar with some lemony notes as well. Very different for a wit - but I have come to expect sourness when I buy Jolly Pumpkin now. Spritzy mouthfeel. Decent.

A great witbier. Slightly different than its competitors in that it retains the slightly sour nature of the JP family (secondary to brewing technique). Nice coriander, spice components without being overpowering. Finish could be a little cleaner for this style. Overall a good brew, but there are better offerings by this brewery.
Bottle from canals in Jersey. Clear yellow pour with big head. Orange and spice aroma. Heavy carbonation taste, a little thin and bland for me. It was ok.

[12 oz bottle] Nice yellow color, with a very slight haze. Pours with a dense white head, diminishes into a short layer. Funky brett aroma, with loads of yeast and lemony citrus. Tart wheat flavors, with some musty oak and lemon. Finishes super dry, with some spicy coriander and plenty of funk character. Overall, an excellent beer, really complex and funky, but so drinkable. Outstanding.
12oz bottle. Cloudy yellow/amber with a medium head and lots of white floaters. Aroma of citrus/lemon, brett, wheat and spices. Taste was sour and funky. Tangy texture. Light body. Candy in a glass.

12 oz bottle from Capones.  Hazy golden in color with a medium to large head.  Aroma of musty yeast, brett, light sour citrus, coriander.  Taste is musty wit yeast, brett, light sour fruit, with spices (coriander).  Finishes tart and spicy.  awesome wit bier.
Not bad, but didnt care for the lemon/fruity finish to this one. Something just isnt right, but cant put my finger on it.  Think Ill pass.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy yellow color with a thin white head.  Aroma of lemon and orange.  Very wine-like.  Nice mouthfeel.  Flavor is sour, with a lemony touch to it.  Not as flavorful as I would have thought.  I expected more of a wine-like taste to it.  A decent sour, but not my favorite.

I tried it from the 12 oz bottle.  Pours well, golden color with small white head.  The taste is very reminiscent of Pinot Grigio.  Dry and crisp with notes of spices around the swallow.  It is a decent witbier overall.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2012 (bottle, thanks olso2116) Pours golden with a small white head and traces of sediment floating in the liquid.  Smell, oh what a surprise for a Jolly Pumpkin, sour and funky, reminiscent of a gueze.  Taste was pretty muted with some sourness, a slight hint of spice, and an oak and grain finish.  Not really that pleasant.

Re-rate:  Definitely wasnt a fan of tart/sour beers when I first rated this, but having tried it again, I found this beer to be really, really good.

Date: 04/29/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Dark Lord Day, 2005

clear yellow, lots of carbonation, big white head, fresh lemony aroma, light citrus malt flavor, simple, 
-------- />
Date: 05/13/2006
Mode: bottle
Score: i to ii

hazy yellow, lemon and spices in the aroma, thin body, very light and lively with lots of carbonation, lots of tart lemon flavor, great spices, dry, 
-------- />

Mode: bottle

bottle explodes in the cellar leaving a small bomb crater moving all other bottles aside

Date: 09/19/2006
Mode: bottle

picking up a bit more funk in the aroma and flavor, carbonation continues to overwhelm, getting more interesting as it grows in character and complexity

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.7/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *4

12 oz bottle, 7/26/07:  Long lasting frothy white head on a medium golden body.  Typical JP house yeast immediately present in the nose... Slighly plasticky/band aid in the phenolics.  It sort of overwhelms the orange floral and peppery character of the yeast.  Some of the ever present barnyardy aromas and wheat malt is moderately present.  Orange and coriander seem to be a bit weak, but this bottle, although refrigerated since being in my posession for the last 3 months, it could be much older.  Well balanced hop/malt wise, and even though a bit aged, it has a nice refreshing tartness to it that not many wits outside Belgium seem to have.  Wheat malt is strong in the flavor profile, as is the yeast character.  Lightly clove spicy, not necessarily peppery spicy.  Higher medium carbonation, lighter body, no alcohol present, dry but well balanced m/f.  Not one of the best wits Ive had, but one of the more interesting.  Im not too keen on the plasticky notes I pick up from JPs house yeast, but this is an interesting beer nonetheles.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 Cloudy pale yellow with good, creamy white head / Funky, perfumey nose of bananas, citrus and oak / Light to medium body, smooth and creamy with low carbonation, a touch of sweetness, and with good, dry finish / Tart flavors of green apple, banana, lemon, orange, and coriander, with black pepper finish / Another superb sour from JP.

Pours a cloudy, pale yellow color with a fluffy, white head.  Highly carbonated.  Aroma of cloves and disinfectant.  Funky, lemony, citrus taste with an almost sour finish.  Theres a lingering, subtle aftertaste of beef jerky...  interesting.

Pours a slightly hazy light straw, with a thin white head.  Pretty strong, singular wheat aroma.  Not too complex.  Odd mix of spices in the flavor.  Id have to say that the coriander dominates with a peppery spiciness.  A bit sour in the finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Interesting sour aroma. Odd flavor of sourness and creaminess, but not in a bad way. Spices are pleasantly mixed and not too fruity. Nice.
Lemon grassy aroma. Pours a pale straw yellow, thin head. Spiciness, tart and acidic finish. Amazingly refreshing!
Cloudy dark yellow. Fair head. Zesty nose, somewhat funky. Fresh bubbly body. Dusty gentle funkiness. Some lemon. Pretty lively beer.

Get a big glass, cause you want to leave that chud in the bottle.  Bottle Conditioned - their not kidding!  Beautiful cloudy white enormous head delicious subtle flavors. (no overwhelming coriander taste)  Excellent!!

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of spices, coriander, nutmeg, cinnamon, Dijon mustard, clove, and a little citrus.  Poured yellow in color with a small white head that diminished quickly.  Cloudy.  Tons of floating particles, big and small.  Flavor is lightly tart, lightly bitter, and lightly sweet.  Tastes of lemon, coriander, clove, and wheat.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Dry, lemon finish.  Overall, not very interesting.

On cask at the Happy Gnome.  I suspect this has more to do with the method of serving than the beer itself.  My pour was a water yellow with no wheat or spice in the nose, just the faintest sourness.  The body was likewise watery with a little more wheat and spice but still underwhelming.

12 oz. bottle poured into a standard pint glass. Another winner from Jolly Pumpkin!  Nice pour with no foam explosion.  Substantial creamy head that never got any thinner than 3/8". It looks like a pure white blanket protecting the beer below, not allowing you to see its goodness even when tilting the glass to drink. Looking at the glass from the side reveals a light straw colored beer, fairly fizzy, and only slightly cloudy. Rarely does a beer look so drinkable. Aroma is yeasty with some citrus. Taste is citrus up front, tart at the end, and yeasty and oaky throughout. Nice dry finish that leaves me wanting more.

Slightly hazy, rich yellow body with dense white foam.  Sour front, bright spices, and a sense of oranges.  The palate is disappointing hollow, slipping off my tongue and not leaving me pleased.  Perhaps it is that it is too dry, as well.  Anyway, it has some good qualities, but I think in a blind tasting I would rate this one much lower than quite a few others in this style.  Bottle.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 cask at Happy Gnome.  Pours a cloudy yellow/gold with a thin white head.  Aroma of wheat, citrus and a bit of spice.  Nice funky cellar flavor to go along with the tart wheat and spice.  Very light and good on a hot day.
UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 On tap. Cloudy light orange gold color. Aroma of wheat, citrus, and spices. Starts sweet, ends slightly sour. Decent. Re-rate. From a bottle. Flavor is much better.

Poured a golden yellow color with a thin white head. The aroma was of citrus fruits, some spices, and a little wheat as well. Definitely get the orange and coriander in the flavor with some wheat characters in there too. I dont get much sourness in there like you would expect from JP. It was really easy drinking and full flavored for this style. It had a tart taste and a nice dry finish from the oak aging. Another really good beer from JP and nicely done for this style. I enjoyed this one a lot, it was really refreshing.
bottle.  hazy wheat pour.  coriander and orange in the nose.  sour taste start to finish with yeasty tast that i enjoyed.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 Interesting sour aroma. Swirling wheat pour, hypnotizing with that gunk on the bottom. Light like a darker lemonade. Odd aroma on top of the foamy head too, like sour berries. Tart and enjoyable, friendly and fun. That is how it starts off with the taste buds. Oh yes, there is the orange peel, more orange flavor in here than Ive ever tasted in a witbier. The orange comes across better than many that have a lemon edge. Quick carbonation that fades quickly after tongue impact. Sour smell continues and even affects the taste!  Grassy and flavorful like those sour clovers that you can eat. No bitterness detected in the flavor or palate. Almost as smooth as many sour apple flavored soda pops. Certainly is wonderful, as the description implies.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle.  Pour is a light gold color with a lot of floaties and a kind of fizzy head.  Aromas are decidedly strange.  Not sure how I feel about them... funky.  Flavor on the other hand is fairly interesting... if you can get past the funk aroma.  Mouthfeel is bubbly and light, and there is the JP tartness to it, but the coriander is there and it compliments things nicely.  Fruity notes abound:  pear and sour apple are the dominant ones.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours light gold with 1 inch of white head. Dense, yellow particles float near the bottom of my glass. Gorgeous, sifting lace. The aroma is delectable and mouth-watering. Layers of wheat, citrus, and flowers are easy to detect. Tastes include coriander, fresh flowers, spice, and a slightly acidic finish with a creamy, seductive mouth-feel. Flavors blend well with the medium body. Well-balanced carbonation. Very good.

12 oz. bottle rating.  Aromas of sour apple, lemon, and barnyard funk.  Body color is cloudy golden with a mostly diminishing head.  Flavor is like sucking on a tart lemon.  Grape, orange.  Finish is quite dry and carbonated, with the signature JP yeast.  Pretty decent brew.  Nice complex flavors hit the palate and make it interesting.

Bouteille 750ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur jaune et semi-voilée. Nez de levures sauvages sûres, fruitées et aux notes acides (agrumes, surtout citron, traces de poires), épicé (coriandre, traces de poivre), moyen de blé et avec de faibles notes boisées et de houblon floral. Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen mais un peu croustillant ainsi quune texture moyennement crémeuse. Goût de levures sauvages fruitées moyennement sûres et aux notes acides (citron, léger dagrumes plus sucrées, notes de pommes vertes, traces de raisins verts ainsi que de bananes et de poires non-mûres, petites notes terreuses) avec un goût épicé (coriandre) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de blé légèrement asséchant et de faibles notes de pain puis en finale lon retrouve une légère amertume de levures aux notes épicées (poivre doux) et des notes de houblon floral et herbeux ainsi quun léger goût boisé (fût de chêne). Post-goût moyen-long et un moyennement sec, aigre de levures fruitées (zest dagrumes, traces de pelures de raisins verts aux petites notes vineuses), aux notes amères de levures et de houblon floral et herbeux ainsi que des notes boisées et de blé.

poured into goblet.  pours a semi-cloudy gold with mild white head.  just as I was checking the nose somebody that just finished smelling in tasting it with me (joe) yelled out "it smells like a McDonalds Cheese Burger", and he was right.  he said that as I was inhaling and could not get past it, it smells like a McDonalds cheeseburger, the mustard and onion, amazing.  on the taste it does not taste as much like it, more yeast, a flat palate, sour front to finish, thruout, coming from the wild yeast and barrel aged, definitly deep and complex

in the 750mL bottle from wild oats. pours a cloudy pale yellow with a thick white head. has a musty and yeasty aroma of a wet horse blanket.  the flavor is much like a tart apple cider that has fully attenuated, but still has some malty thickeness left to it. has a pleasant crisp finish that leaves a mild pear taste in the mouth. this beer does not have the nasty acidity that so many of this style seem to. as it warms, a discernable oakiness emerges that makes the beer quite drying. it has a very orange-like finish.  delicious!

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 Pours a yellowish color.  Aroma is spiced with bubblegum, which I must say I never understood until smelling this beer.  The flavor is quite tart, moreso than other Belgian whites Ive tried.  Its very fruity, with again a flavor of bubblegum.  Slightly spicy too.  There is a hint of oak (a Jolly Pumpkin signature it seems), that gives a dry finish.  Overall, its quite tart, fruity, and pretty refreshing.      Unique.

750 ml bottle.  Hazy pale golden beer, creamy white head.  Quite a good-looking brew.  Soft fruity aroma up front with light bretty mustiness.  Earthy and slightly leathery with a soft sourness apparent as well.  Lemony citrus and very bright smelling with loads of wheaty spice as well.  No real orange but the coriander is definitely present.  Soft lemony flavour with a touch of wheaty spice.  Light yeasty spiciness as well.  Warming brings up a lovely fruitiness white grape, apple and a soft floral character as well.  Finishes quite dry.  Crisp and refreshing I like this brew.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2009 NorCal tasting July 07 - I could seriously get into this beer. It has all the nice character that I like in my wits, plus it brings the funk which is always nice. A sharp lemony, orangy sweet aroma, lightly spicy with subtle corriander hints. Appearance was a pale, pale yellow, cloudy with a smaller sized white head. Brett played a big time role in the flavor of this beer, orange notes, lemongrass, a bit dusty with a dry finish. It almost had some wine-like character to this beer. I definitely recommend this beer as it is really beer apart. On a side note, excellent labels from JP.

Re-Rate 5/28/2009
OK, this bottle was not quite as good as my first one, which was some time ago.  This had almost no wit character at all, flat on the front end of things (flavor wise, not carbonation) with a high degree of funkiness.  Missing were any semblance of fruit.  Seemed like a mini-gueuze at times.  Still, enjoyable as it was I didnt enjoy it nearly as much as I did the first time.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 Cloudy white gold appearance.  Lovely and unique nose sensations.  Autumn leaves, balsamic vinegar, and that unmistakable j/p apple tartness.  Further notes of sourdough and a bit of salt.  Coriander, cayenne, white pepper and partially reduced pears on the tongue.  Spicy, lively, and a little crazy.  Finishes on a dry desert shrub sensation.  Palate is strawlike - taut, earthy.  A different and interesting take on the style that is far more pleasing than plain yeast and sugar.  Simply lovely.

Open this over the sink!  The bottle conditioning gushed out of the bottles I had.  Thick long lasting white head makes it difficult to drink.  Flavors have a nice oak background with a musty aftertaste.  Good spice notes in the aroma.  Pleasant, but frustrating to loss so much in over flow.

A great take on one of my favorite styles. Aroma of yeast, oak and lemon. Pours was a cloudy white with a nice one finger white head. Taste was citrus, coriander and spicy with a faint wood and sweetness in the aftertaste. I like the tartness in the beginning but I could do without the oak flavor. Oh well, it was different and good.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Like a Hoegaarden crossed with an Orval.  Typical slight funky sourness that JP is well known for.  I like it but found the lactic sourness just a bit misplaced in this offering.  Refreshing summer brew nonetheless.

Nice aroma of wheat and spice, pours a clear light yellow, with a quickly fading white head, and just a light speckling of yeast floating within.  Wonderful crisp taste, nice spicing, and carbonation to lift it all off the tongue.  Amazingly tasty on a sweaty summer night.

Hazy, ugly, but quite luminous yellow pour with white light cast forth. A tall white, rocky head is very well retained and leaves thick webs of lacing behind, eventually. Spice dominates the nose in the form of notes of pepper, yeast and crisp, unripened citrus. Quickly following are aromas of oak, vanilla, tangerine and sweet mandarin nectar, alcohol that really shouldnt be noticeable at such a low strength. Banana and wheat notes round out the nose. The flavor is incredibly spicy and peppery, with yeast spiraling forward like a stormcloud. Bitterness is mild, acidity is moderate, sweetness medium. Finishes very dry, yeasty and spicy. the mouthfeel is light, crisp, gritty and lively due to robust carbonation and engrossing tannins. A pretty wild witbier.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy golden yellow with a copious white head.  Spicy nose with just a touch of twang.  Light, refreshing body with loads of carbonation.  Orange and spice come to the front and dissolve into a nice crisp finish.

Pours a very light golden color.  Slight head that disipates rather quickly. Smell is spicy, but somewhat reserved.   Smell is carbonated, with some wine like flavors.  Im getting some lemon zest as well as some white grapes. Very crisp, refreshing and easy drinking.  Not the funk bomb that is anticipated, but a good beer nonetheless.
Bottle. Pours hazy bubbly gold with floaters, white head. Aroma is coriander, nutmeg, lemon, banana, wheat. Flavor is the same, very wheaty and slightly musty funky bleu cheese.
Strong aroma of orange and coriander. Pours light yellow, clear, with a moderate head. Mild mouth feel with a spicy, lightly tart flavor. All around excellent beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy brownish yellow with a fizzy white head that quickly recedes to a thin film that leaves a little lacing.  It has some chunky yeasties in the bottom.

The aroma is musty yeast, wheat, some floral hops and sweet and tart citrus.

The flavor is musty earthy yeast with some peppery spices and some tart and slightly sour citrus.  The mouthfeel is is medium with a ton of sharp carbonation.

Overall, an enjoyable lighter beer.  Its interesting for a wit - a little more tart fruits than spices.  This is more of what I was expecting from the Bam Biere.

Hazy golden with a torrent of carbonation coming off the bottom. Big off white head. Sweet fresh floral, light yeast and citrus aroma. Taste is very different from your normal Witbier. Very light, but is tart with a dry finish. Light and refreshing. When it comes down to it, I enjoy the taste but there just isnt enough there for me.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 Bottle. Pours hazy gold with a thin bright white head. Pleasant sweet and sour aroma. Hints of orange peel, pineapple, sour yeast and new oak. Lively carbonation. Very refreshing flavor profile. Decent amount of dry hops and yeast with some citrus sweetness and some lemon zest sourness. Hints of bananas as well. Excellent summer beer.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2010 Almost clear yellow body with a small white head.  For a witbier the nose is very funky, like someone poured some gueuze in a classic witbier.  First impression when drinking it is that it reminds me of their wonderful Bam Biere.  Similar intense fruity tartness and sourness but without the support of the Bam Biere body.
