Very lemony, pineapples and all kind of tropical fruits, dry orange peels, many spices including the classic coriander, even some dandelions.  So far so good, so far so very good actually.  But it gets better.   Next comes a woody/barrel character that leads to a dry finish and this is what makes it stand out.  A the beer warms-up the woody/barrel flavours begin to take over the fruity notes.  Oily body with a medium-soft carbonation.  Very flavourful and complex by witbier standards.  The only problem with the beer is the similarities with the superior Bam Biere. A 750ml goes by more quickly than a 16 year-old backstage after a New Kids On The Block concert.

12oz bottle - Pours out with a small white head. You can really smell the orange spice and coriander. Taste has a bit of the spice their, too. Refreshing, had this on a hot day and found it to be really nice. Not the best of the style and a little pricey, but a good try.

12 oz. bottle from AJs (Tucson) - Pours a hazy light golden color with a 1/2 finger thick white head.  Very light spotty lacing.  Aroma is light citrus, spice, and light yeast.  Flavor is bitter and almost sour (Lambic like).  Not what I was expecting for a Wit.   Light body.   Worth a try, I guess.

In general... meh... I had puirchased the bottle about 6 months ago, and maybe its better fresh, but at this point the brett funk had taken over the aroma and flavor.  The appearance was spot on, but the flavor and aroma elements were all about the funk.  Tasty beer, maybe better fresh.
user_location: Port Jefferson Station, New York, USA

text: Bottle. Not much aroma to speak of. Soapy white head. Picked up the orange and coriander, also the sour / funk that is Jolly Pumpkin. Not a bad beer, but not my favorite Wit.

750 mL bottle.  Hazy honey yellow with big fluffy white head.  Aroma of citrus, spice and yeast.  Initially lively palate.  Taste orange and yeasty with the coriander showing through toward the end.  Has a clean finish with almost no lingering taste, but it does develop a good tartness as it warms.

From bottle in Hoegaarden glass.  Pours very pale, cloudy orange with orange-tinted-white, lasting head with nice lacing, definitely a nice appearance.   Surprisingly light tart orange and spice aroma.  Flavor is pleasantly tart, like other JP beers, but the tartness in this one seems to overwhelm the other subtle flavors of orange, spice, and wheat. These flavors seem a little more present as the beer warms up a bit. Body is light-medium as it should be, very slightly overcarbonated giving it a bite on the tongue in the finish.  A very refreshing brew that I would drink again, but the refreshing tartness is a little much in such a subtle and delicate style.

Love the touch of sour, the orange peel in the aroma, the subtle spiciness, the all around refreshingness.  Golden color, pretty clear.  My first beer from Jolly Pumpkin, cant wait to try some more.  Great summer beer.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 750 ml bottle courtesy Boutip. Classic wit appearance - hazy pale yellow with a fully lasting rich creamy white head. Heavy spicy and acidic coriander and orange peel aroma with peppery and toasty notes. Acidic and tart citrus flavour with a dry yeasty and nutty bitter finish. Light to medium bodied, creamy and fizzy mouthfeel. Maybe a bit too tart for a wit, but nicely refreshing.

Bouteille de 750 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur dagrumes et dépices. Apparence: La couleur est blonde pâle légèrement voilée avec une forte densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de citron et de zeste dorange avec une pointe de coriandre et gingembre. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de citron en arrière goût. (Rating #1039)

Jolly Pumpkin Calabaza Blanca
750 ml bottle
Recent brewing, cleansed 05/07
Moderate pour in a mug.

Poured a hazy straw color with a huge rocky white head with fair lacing.

Smelt of strong fresh oranges and lemons, coriander, light bread and dough.

Taste was upfront strong sour orange and lemon juice with light to moderate bread notes followed by moderate sour oranges and lemon and bitter doughy yeast on an average finish.

Palate was light to medium bodied, lively carbonated, slightly dry on a dry finish, moderately puckering and slightly astringent.

Overall, this is a nice soft introduction to the sour beers of Jolly Pumpkin.  The people whom Ive shared this with, none of them being big craft beer drinkers, were very pleased with it.  The sourness intrigues but doesnt overwhelm.  Not my personal favorite Jolly Pumpkin though.

12 oz. bottle.  Pour into my small weizen resulted in the explosive science experiment white head--foamy and craggy, creating a tall peak above the rim.  Beer itself was ginger ale colored and very bubbly, with some yeast swirls.  Aroma was slightly sour with some barnyard.  Initially, tart and musty flavor leaving some light grass and a "lemon squeeze" on the finish.  Mellows out after some time, where some of the orange peel/coriander notes come through.  Robust, but not overbearing carbonation. Craftsmanship shows, but I doubt Id spend the same for this one.

Bottle from Holiday wine cellar. Hazy yellow pour with a decent frothy white head. Smells of citrus, spice, and hops. Tastes really refreshing woth so many different tastes. As it warmed the spices really came through. Very good witbier.

Cloudy yellow, very thin white head. Tart, lemony aroma, with a notes of pears, apples and white wine. Flavor is earthy, tart, oaky, winey, spicy, citrusy, smoky, dusty - I could go on. I was really surprised how much i liked this one.
I like this wit. Closer to fruit than spice taste for me. I enjoy the carbonation. The first time i tasted this i was taken by surprise and have gone back to it several times since.

bottle from Kingdom Liquors - it was fun yet sad that while I had an easter party the group drank all of my Corona and Bud Light and wouldnt share my craft beers - oh well!  Sweet and ginger taste and can taste the corriander - very very tasty
funky town.... some of the fun ranch white pepper and lemon, corriander, herbs.  i like the funky cheese flavor in the foreground.  yum.

Pours a relatively clear light gold with a medium white head.  A little cloudy.  Smells of light spices, slight acidity, and some citrus fruit.  Taste has some fruitiness to it, mostly orange, slight wheat characters, and some spiciness.  Really easy drinking beer.  Just a touch of some sourness in true JP fashion.  finish is pretty smooth and full of flavor.  Good beer.

Vibrant yellow in colour with strong carbonation. Not too much haze for a witbier. Strong coriander aromas with secondary notes of marjoram, lemon, and a bo of oat. Spritzy and light in the mouth, with a moderate amount of lactic sourness. The herbal character is stronger in the mouth, as are the oats. Focused and clean finishing citrus finish.
Lots of "floaties" in straw colored---very bland---brew. It did have a tart taste. Certainly no hops.

Pours a golden color with a white head.  Aroma is of orange, lemon, coriander, and yeast.  I pick up a very subtle oak flavor with plenty of the spices, orange, and lemon.  A pretty decent belgian style brew.  Definetely worth having again.
Robe jaune paille légèrement voilée surmontée dune mousse blanche épaisse qui sestompe. Arômes de blé, de levures et de curaçao. Saveurs de blé, doranges, de coriandre et de levures.

Bottle from Shawan Liquors in Cockeysville, MD. Pours a hazy pale golden with a big rocky white dissipating head. Aroma of yeast, citrus zest, and coriander. Mouthfeel is medium light, with a thin (but not watery) texture. Flavor of lemon, spice, and orange peel with a moderate amount of tartness. I do not pick up much oak, but I do get some flavors of white wine- perhaps Chardonnay. Finish is dry with notes of peppercorn and yeast. Ill go out on a limb and say parts of this remind me of a gueze. Very well done and refreshing, but I prefer my witbiers to have a little more malt backbone. No flaw with the beer, just a personal preference.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of bu11zeye,thanks! The pour reveals a cloudy golden color with a thin, frothy white head. Very appealing aroma of coriander, orange peel, citrus and yeast. The flavor is very tart and sour, it feels like lemon juice, the orange peel and coriander are overwhelmed by the lemon juice feeling, its very sharp, dry and refreshing, I would be happy to drink this in hot summer days. The palate is a witbier classic, round, smooth and creamy, the carbonation gentle. A very solid witbier, knowing the brewery its no surprise!

Medium yellow pour, a lot of long lasting fizzy white head (at least 3 times in a 20 oz glass for a 12 oz bottle,) went from clear to murky as it finally built (at least a coupleof minutes,) lively carbonation, yeasty sediment, evident orange peel smell, much better as it sits, straw maly, light citrus hop, a little spice I guess that is coriander, very tart, dry sour finish.  Not my favorite style but a decent attempt.

12oz bottle into a Weizen glass. Pours a wonderfully hazy, cloudy, particle filled golden orange. Huge, pillowy white head. Very nice lacing. Oranges, lemon, citrus, spice and yeast on the nose. I guess that is coriander in there as well, because I pick up something different that I cant quite put my finger on. Smells wonderful. Fore of the tongue is astringent, spicy, filled with citrus and oranges. Back of the tongue brings more of the same, with the yeast shining through. Some sour notes in there as well. Finishes very abruptly, dry, clean. Very nice brew.

Pours yellow w/ a full, semi spritzy froth that hangs around for a while. Residual lacing is exceptional. Huge rocky mounds and a thick, snowy blanket. Like a topograhical map of a snow covered landscape. Aroma is all lemons and perfume. Light to medium nectar w/ an abundance of residual effers complete w/ Champagne streamers. Delicate flavors of lemony citrus juice dominate w/ a perpetual bittering that sets in quick. A mild perfume factor is enjoyable. Slight oak and spice to add complexities. The finish is slightly tart and crisp w/ a perfect bittering agent. Overall: light and refreshing w/ nothing to be ashamed of.

poured from a 12oz. bottle into a weiss glass

A: Poured beautifully with a big, luscious head just like a witbier should, though it went away fairly quickly. Very cloudy yellow/orange from massive amounts of yeast.

S: Delicious smell, loads of orange & coriander right up front. Slight spiciness, slight earthy mustiness to it.

T/M: Flavor switches gears a bit, far more lemony citric than orange. Very tart with an extremely dry finish. Good carbonation and quite refreshing.

D: I probably wouldnt drink a ton of these by choice, but I also wouldnt complain about sucking down a half-dozen poolside or on the beach. This is a really nice warm-weather beer.
Foggy gold, thin white head.  Aroma is horseblanket, yeast, and grapefruit.  Taste is citrus, spice, light yeast, and a wheat character to it.

Nice aroma of grains, spice, citrus, orange, and lemon.  Pour is a slightly hazy gold yellow with a puffy head.  Flavors of wheat, coriander, orange, lemon, and some sourness.  A nice refreshing, easy to drink beer.

Bottled.  Via trade with drewbeerme. Murky wit shade of yellow with a big, frothy white head.  Yeasty aroma with tons of coriander some cinnamon and a bit of orange.  Light and very dry with a slight tartness.  Lemongrass, oranges, bananas, coriander and spices.  Highly carbonated.  Dry and tart finish.  A very complex beer for what I usually think of as a somewhat simple flavored style.  I think enjoying this beer may rely a lot on what kind of mood youre in at the time you drink it; Im sitting in my backyard during the late afternoon and Im really enjoying it, I could see opening it in other situations, however, and being a bit put off by it.

Cold 750ml bottle:  Pours a hazy straw color with a moderate head that dissolves into a thin layer of alabaster bubbles and a thick ring of bubbles around the edges.  Aroma is of coriander, orange zest, sharp yeast and lemon.  Taste is of light grains and spice with citrus zing and tart notes.  Light bodied, playful carbonation and crisp.  Ending is grainy and dry with tart notes.

12 oz bottle, poured very hazy yellow with a puffy head.  Dry aroma with yeast, lemon, and "funk."  Taste was kind of sour, oaky, and had a bit of wine or something.  Very nice and dry, I loved it in the summertime.

Bottle.  Lots of coriander with orange peel, lemon, and yeast.  Sickly hazy yellow with a very short white head.  Tart taste with a little chalk and lemon, light yeast with a smooth, pleasant maltiness.  Medium body.  Sourish, spicy tang leads the way out.  Bit of a dry champagne aftertaste.  Decent if somewhat bland for a wit, but Im already reaching for something else (and I love sourness).

12 oz bottle from Pantanap, Thanks Kan! Nose of tartness, yeast, apples, and spices; Hazy yellow with a medium yellowish head; flavor of mild lemony tartness, bready yeast, and the coriander. Body is medium-light with a slightly tart finish. Pretty good!

12oz bottle - Toronado
Pours: Straw yellow slightly hazy with a huge billowy white head which lasts for a long time
Palate: Relatively light bodies with the tartness and the medium high carbonation.. a great fit for a summer afternoon
Nose: Floral, base malts, some musty and lemony notes.. 
Flavor: opening notes of base (wheat like) malt notes with some spicy hop bite with some fruitiness before the the blast of lemony (some pith) cleansing tartness along with some woody notes washes over... 
Overall: WOW! what a great beer.. for something under 5% is fantastic... almost like "Temptation or Saison Dupont LITE" so much going on.... a great summer beer... but hey a cloudy day in SF is not a bad choice either.. I would chalk this under another one of the masterful beers from Jolly Pumpkin.. Cheer Ron!

750 ml bottle. It pours a straw yellow with creamy white head with good lacing. The tartness of lemon in the nose that come though in the flavor with the added complexity of a slight woodsy and spicy character in the finish.  Well made beer.

clear like water, almost not even yellow at all, very carbonated, big white head which eventually turns into nothing, citrus tea flavor, grapes, champagne like, delicate, slightly bitter on the finish, very well done

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2007 12oz bottle....poured a hazy golden hue with nice white head, and bubbly carbonation lasted several minutes.Aroma was of a wheat beer, citrus-like and reminded me of warmer months.taste was lemony-tart, refreshing, dry but without much of lasting sensation. It ended very abruptly in my eyes .mouthfeel was okay, high level of carbonation but added to its refreshing nature.  not too bad of a beer but ive had better before.
I felt lots of coriander and other spices in this, a bit leathery and earthy. Bitter apples like a sour cider in the mix. FInishes with a lemony zest and sour malts.

Cloudy yellow with big thick white head.
Strong spicy aroma .
Big spicy flavor with citrus, apples and oranges.
Good stuff!

Medium golden color - fairly clear and bubbly and a big fluffy and fairly dense head.  Aroma of apples, lemon, bready yeast and orange peel.  Flavor is quite fruity - strong presence of orange and apple, with a nice wheat tartness. A little spiciness from the coriander towards the end.  Fairly dry and clean finish.

12oz bottle: pours a nice golden hay colour with a very white fluffy head that stays. aroma of sweet malts yeast and spice with a hint of citrus. very dry and woody taste some spice and sweet malts and a dry bitter finish. very clean tasting beer. with a yeasty after taste
Yeast and spice dominate the aroma.Pours a hazy gold with a large white frothy head.Lots of spices in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with some sourness and spice in the finish.

Somewhat of a gusher.  Aroma of green apples, ginger, and yeast.  Appears a hazy yellow with an overzealous rocky white head.  Flavor of lemon, coriander and yeast - some horsey notes - with a peppery finish.  Palate is light and appropriately carbonated, but very very dry.  Overall, a wit that does not quite hit the mark.

12 oz bottle purchased at Papago in Scottsdale, AZ. Poured a slightly hazy pale yellow color. Head was big and bubbly. Aroma was typical coriander, orange zest, and yeasty bread dough. Very effervescent and acidic up front. The acidity fades a bit and gives way to bready malt and fruit flavors accented by coriander and a bit of sea salt.

12oz bottle from Artusory. Poured wtih a massive white head. There is the familiar taste of coriander and orange peel, under the wheat flavor. This one is a bit thin, but a decent example of Belgian-style witbier.

12oz bottle, courtesy of drewbeerme.  Thanks, Andrew!  Pours a hazy golden color; significant white head with strong lacing.  Pleasant aroma with a light tartness from the brett (without overwhelming the witbier profile underneath).  Champagne-like crispness and acidity in the mouthfeel: plenty of coriander, watery oranges, and dough, nicely brought alive by the brett character.  Light, doughy and citrus finish.  I actually enjoyed their work with the Leelanau Whaleback White a bit more than this.
Bottle @ Toronado.  Golden color with a white head.  Champaign and white wine like with a spritzy palate.  Orange, pepper, citrus and light mustiness, with a light refreshing finish.

I hate wits, in general.  But I truly enjoyed this beer.  After a terrible day of $250 in books being stolen from my desk in the lab, I came home still miserably angry, but was talked into cracking one open.  Not wanting to waste the "good stuff," I went to this interesting looking Belgian white.  Wow, not bad!  Its a clear pallid yellow without the yeast dumped in (the bottle is simply too big for me to get the yeast a glass at a time!).  The nose is tart and tangy with a light wheatiness about it, rather than that dominating grainy aroma.  Very tart, lemon, with a bit of creaminess.  Orange zest and some light spices present.  A bit of that Belgian and open fermentation twang.  This is a very nice beer indeed aroma-wise.  The palate is quite nice as well, creamy and full, though perhaps a bit fizzy.  The flavors are even bigger and louder than the subtle aromas would indicate.  Incredibly, ridiculously tart.  Lemon and that open fermentation yogurt twang stick out.  Theres a light sweetness, and a bit of yeast and orange, but a huge sour point.  Not balanced, but I dont mind!  Yeast takes off some of the edge, makign this perhaps a bit more drinkable for the unprepared, but I liked it better undampened.

Golden yellow color with a medium white head.  Smells like orange, general citrus, malt and spices.  There is sourness in the flavor but also malty and sugary with some lemon.  Tart finish.   Very drinkable but still such a full flavor, nice.

With the yeast stirred up and poured in, the beer is a cloudy straw color, topped by about two inches of frothy white foam. Lots of carbonation stirs up some small dark flecks of yeast. Good head retention and spotty but thick lacing. Tangy wheat, lemon, and yeast are found in the aroma - very nice.

The beer is tangy, almost to the point of being funky, with full flavors of wheat and a lemony citrus character. The coriander is subtle but still noticeable. Dry wheat, orange, and coriander come out in the finish, and the tangyness sticks around in the aftertaste.

Light to medium body, excellent carbonation.

12oz bottle thanks to Drewbeerme: It was cold coming out of the box today so I figured I would drink it immediately. Hazy golden color with a medium sized white head. Aroma, yeasty, some spice, coriander, light fruits, a little peppery. Flavor, bready, spicy, some fruits, a nice tartness. Good stuff.
Pours light orange with a huge fluffy white head.  Tastes of spicy yeast, citrus peel, and coriander.  Very light bodied and thin feeling.

All I can say is WOW. This is some unreal sh**. Poured with an enourmous white head, a slight hazy golden color. Awesome aroma that smelled of oranges and cloves and corriander. Not at all heavy in the mouth, nicely fizzy and finishes with a nice tartness. Very Very good stuff.

This is a really nice white ale. Alot of protein in this one, as the ginormous head adopted a pointed meringue of a peak and held it forever. Appropriately cloudy yellow-gold. Nice aroma, not strong, but distinctive with lots of coriander, just a touch of orange peel, and maybe a hint of lemon - there was also a fresh dough note in the background. Flavor surprisingly dry from front to back, with the coriander being restrained in favor of a light citrus punch and mild tartness. Finish was dry and semi-clean. Almost creamy palate. Interesting  and well done witbier.

Light white frothy head.  Great carbonation keeps the head constantly regenerating.  Light gold in color.  Light and crisp flavor with lemon and grass.  Finishes dry with a light tartness.  I will have to try this one again and have a better go at it.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2007 Light, hazy orange-gold color with monster amounts of foam.  Sweet aroma of orange & spice.  Sweet, bready, spicy tastes that are very refreshing.  About the best you can find in a Wit.

This was a really good sour-ish belgian wit. Nice bright golden yellow with a fluffy large white head. Citrusy aroma, orangey and good flavor. Dry zesty finish witih slight bretty acid. Good stuff. Bottle is likely a year old and has held up well. It is very balanced and maybe the age has helped.

12 oz bottle.  Leave it to JP to make a great beer of a style I am not a huge fan of.  Lots of citrusy fruitiness in this aroma.  Hazy yellow pour with huge white head under the aroma.  Flavors were similar with a decent wheat twang.  Pretty good.

750. Beer is hazy, light pale gold with a large, frothy, white, diminishing head. Seagulls of lace on the glass.

The aroma is malty with a light note of toasted grain; Hoppy with a moderate note of lemon zest, light note of pine resin; Yeasty with a light note of sharp band-aid; Trace of orange zest, light coriander and white pepper.

The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, trace bitter with a longish, lightly acidic, trace sweet finish.

The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.
This is an excellent wit, prolly the best one Ive ever had.  Nice and spicy with a good mouthfeel.  Very balanced and refreshing.  Good Stuff.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Huge, voluminous white head which takes some time to settle. Spicy, slightly bretty aroma with some unbuttered popcorn. Slight perfume hints as well, and somewhat, uh, footy. Flavor begins at fist as a delicately pastry-like doughiness, followed by a rather harsh tartness. Substantial bitterness covers over a prominent lemoniness. All this, combined with a strong carbonation makes for quite an in-you-face beer. Tarty and bitter doesnt work amazingly well for me.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 12oz bottle. very pale and light, not hazy at all. not over carbinated like some bottles of this stuff. i think this was a little too fresh because ill i can taste is coriander and banana. aroma has a lot of banana in it too. finishes dry and peppery. ive had bottles of this that i liked a lot more, so i ll have to rerate after i age for a few months.6/3/6/2/10=2.5 

6/15/07, bottle. i forgot to take notes but i found this beer around when clearing out my cellar. wow i enjoyed this bottle a lot more. very fresh and fruity, funky, and a real joy to drink. 7/4/7/4/15=3.7. 

4/21/08, its a been awhile since ive had this but i found some 12oz singles at a store and good thing since this has been discontinued in 12oz format. pours hazy light golden with white head. bottle is probably 6-12months old. a big bretty lemony aroma. wonderful. flavors are dry lemon drop sour and a touch of wheat. okay so theres no orange peel and coriander and this is bretty funktastic making this way out of style but who cares, its in awesome JP fashion. i love it and could drink it constantly.3.9.
cloudy white beer with a medium sized white head.  lemony aroma.  woody citrus flavors.  not really much else.  hard to find the spices.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2008 What a fine beer from a fine brewery. Pours cloudy light orange with an enormous uneven sudsy white head. The aroma has more coriander than most wits - offsetting it is smoothness from the wheat and a hint of orange. Medium / light body that is very crisp with some very smooth carbonation complimenting the sharp biting taste. The taste starts with sour yeast as many Jolly Pumpkins do, there is also a good amount of coriander and some citrus bite. The finish has a ton of coriander and even more sharpness. This comes across as a cross between a wit and biere de garde, which isnt surprising since this is from Jolly Pumpkin. Excellent wit.

Rerate notes: The aroma has whats listed above, but also some notes from the barrel aging. There is some dry orange in there, quite a bit of graininess and some oak. While it is quite a bit more expensive than other wits, it is so unique and interesting that I dont feel ripped off. Cheers to Jolly Pumpkin for this fantastic beer.

Bottle.   Pours cloudy golden color with massive white head and huge lacing.   Aroma is oak, floral, orange, wheat.   Flavor is oak, floral, sweet orange, spice.   Palate is light, dry, super crisp and tart, higly carbonated.   Love this!

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2006 The brew is aged in oak casks and then re-fermented in a bottle. Gold color with a large white head. Strong smell of oak and wheat. Somewhat sweet taste, floral, and oaky, with a tart dry finish. Refreshing. Very nice lighter beer.

Bottle.  Clear honey-gold color with a big, frothy white head.  Spicy aroma (orange peel and the coriander are apparent), apples, yeast, light hops, sweet malts.  Quite sweet smelling, and tasting.  More spices, very sweet, light hops, pronounced tartness.  Floral and tropical.  Dry finish. Very bubbly on the tongue.  A nice beer, light and sweet, but I think its just a less balanced version of the oro de calabaza.

Pours a cloudy orange color. Nich milk shake frothy head... Very tarty kind of like a warhead candy. Hints of sour apple, grapefruit, lemon peel (not Lime). I didnt get a the dry finish i thought i would. This beer grew on me i wish i had some good cheese to pair with this.

Bomber from Beer Depot in Ann Arbour, MI- Pours milky hazy yellow with a fluffy, creamy, cappucino head. Lots of floaties too. Nose is spices, curacao,candy, with lots of brett. Funky orange  peel citric flavours are unique. Spices and flowers filter through to the finish. Very tart and refreshing. Good on ya Ron!
Ah, what can I say. Not a belgin fan, least fav is white ales.  Got some spice in the nose, body was light yellow, small white head. Light body, good brew.

Hazy orange straw in appearance with a large tight white pillowy head.  The best Ive ever seen actually.  Wow, great nose.  Very intense apricot, lavender, orange juice, white pepper, vanilla.  I could smell this all day and get different things out of it.  Sourness is immediate with orange peel, sour apricot, and clove rounding out the flavors with mild mild hops.  It has the bark of a wolf with the bite of a chihuahua.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2007 12 oz bottle.  This is hardly recognizable as a wit, and that is ok.  The aroma has lots of spice, yeast, and light barnyard weirdness.  Looks great, nearly a gusher.  The foam is very long lasting and get thin but leaves a tall layer on top of the beer.  Lots of sediment settled in the bottom of the glass.  One of the best looking beers I have ever seen. Taste is of summer.  Fresh fruit, lots of citrus and lightly sour like a biere de garde.  Refreshing; I probably should be drinking this on a hot day.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2017 Pours  a faint gold with a white foamy head that stands its ground and effervescing in the glass, lacing is plentiful, spicy citrus with apple, pear and a hint of funky wood in the aroma, faint malt and wheat fragrances, coriander spice aroma throughout, lots of carbonation on the tongue, light and tart in the mouth, and has a dry finish.

25 oz bottle, Stateline Liquors.  Pours a clear bright yellow gold colored body under a craggy and foamy meringue like head that stuck up almost an inch above the rim of my glass.  Rather vigorous visible carbonation.  Aroma is light and fruity with a good dose of belgian spices, lots of coriander and bitter orange peel.  Rather dry with some yeastiness.  Flavor is spicey as well with a very light soft maltiness.  Finishes sharp and bone dry with a touch of brett maybe?  Very delicate flavor.  Alot of floral perfumy flavors.  Mouthfeel is extremely fizzy in its carbonation.  So much so that it foams on contact with the tongue.  Otherwise, fairly light bodied and airy.  Overall, this was light and easy drinking.  The most subtle of all the JPs Ive had so far.  A good first JP for those who may be a little weirded out by some of their more extreme beers.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Firemoose. Thanks. Lots of carbonation. Golden with a small crisp white head. Orange, funk, vinegar and yeast dominate the palate. This is a belgian white?  Smells kinda funky. But I like funk. Taste is more tart and sour with sweet notes but the acididity definately overwhelms the palate. This is a toss-up rating because I really love sour beers and this definately sour, but its a bit out of character for the beer its supposed to be. Interesting and maybe one to revisit. Tried some of a friends big bottle some months ago and dont remember it being that sour.

12oz bottle from The Foodery. Cloudy, golden appearance. Earthy, musty aroma. Tart flavors dominate the palate, but the beer also possesses the citric notes typical of the style. Not as interesting as JPs other offerings, but still very enjoyable, and Im sure it will make its way into my fridge again soon.
Nice hazy appearance, with a lemony aroma and flavor.  Slightly too acidic, and a bit too much of a dry finish.  Interesting white ale -- I think I need to try this one again to get a better rating.

Light yellow with a medium white head. Funky aroma, not much wheat. Big oak flavour, slightly tart. For me the oak seemed to overpower any other flavours that may have been present. Not bad but kinda one dimensional.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2006 Beer pours light gold, very cloudy, with very, very thick and dense head. The head is comprised of variously sized-bubbles and sticks to the glass in a heavy lace. The aroma has a soft coriander noise with sour fruit. The taste begins very tart and a little acidic. Some wheat, yeast, and bitter orange appear in the middle. The beer finishes dry with some hop bitterness, more wheat, more citrus, and more tartness. The after-taste is very mild (tart fruit, bitter orange peel). A rather tart example of a Belgian Wit, that tastes weak in wheat and oat, but strong in other traditional flavors (orange, coriander)
Coludy and yellow with minimal head. Light wheat orange peel and corriander in both the flavour and aroma.  Pretty basic example of a wit.

Pale yellow, thin white head.  Nose was uninteresting, faint clove adn corriander.  First impression was tart, herbal and hinted at dirt and twigs.  Did not improve on the finish.  Unimpressed overall.
Light hazy yellow.  Slightly woody, leathery on the top of the spice.  Tart, fairly bland, wheaty.  Not much to say.
The weakest of the JP beers.  I think I need to try it again though.  Props for not being an over the top wit like Leinie wheat that my girlfriend just bought.

Musty sweet nose.  Pours golden yellow with a slightly cloudy appearance.  Huge bubble production that produces a white foam head.  Sharp sour taste with a crisp dry ending.  Nice smooth mouth feel.  The captain has done a really consistent job in packaging this 6-er.  Flavor is rich sour taste, but not overpowering as long as you dont let it sit in the glass too long.  Not a  chance of that happening.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2006 Bright electric yellow with magical lines of bubbles flowing to the surface of perfect white foam.  Aroma of lemon zest are very abundant.  Very dry finish.  Mouthfeel of a lambic but  the smoothness of a creamy ale.  Slight sour apple flavors as well.  This beer was an amazing find.  Thick laminated label on a 12 oz. bottle.

Pours a light hazy golden with a fizzy but large head.  Aroma is tart- lemon herbs, DMS and corn-like with more citrus hints.  Herbal citrus flavor with more graininess and DMS, and a tart lemony finish.  Nice and clean and surprisingly not yeasty for a wit.

bottle. Huge head that quits down but resembles Chouffe Houblon. Mildly sweet aroma. Taste is a well balanced blend of spices and citrus. Very smooth with low carbonation. Great for a hot day. Cheers!

Bottle. Pours a golden straw color, with a big foamy white head, no lacing. Smells spicy with some sweet citrus at first, with a few yeasty notes here and there. It tastes super tart for a witbeer, kinda like sour lemons, finishes drier than an Arizona summer. Super carbonated... its got some bite too it too. Kind of weird overall for a witbeer, but interesting in a decent way.

Bottle. Worked pretty well for me in the end. Typical coriander spiceyness and slight lemony tart characters. This was better in the fact that it had a lovely refreshing sour edge, certainly much more interesting than your average wit, although there was still something missing.

funkey bacterial aroma (infecto?) waay more sunkey than i was expecting from a white beer supposed to wash some pizza down - . kinda dissapointing aroma actually. smells like it might be bad, if so, second bad beer from foodery II.  Well, its spicy, kinda spunky.  I think its probably supposed to be this way.  I really dont like this combo of spices, it crops up every so often, though usually not in witbiers.  ITs like some kinda coriander overload with mustard seeds and vegetables / parsley rhubarb.  effin yuck, still a good quality beer but I hate what they did with the style - not to my taste at all.  Extremely tart-sour palate, all lemon. Boo. finishable but not one to return to.

750ml bottle pours hazy golden with a big white head that stays briefly and then fades with little lacing.  Aromas of yeast, brett, orange, and corriander.  Flavors of nice lemon, orange, some yeast, and a good amount of the usual brett funk that you find in JP brews.  Lively carbonation and light body finish is dry.  Pretty nice brew overall.  Very unique wit..

Bottle. Im really happy I have more.  Aroma sour citrus,lemony a tad of yeast.   Poured a hazen golden,bright,light white cap.  Flavor was of orange peel and spice.  Palate was tart and lively with a nice mouthfull creamy bubbliness. Finish was actually quite quick with a rather dry tail.  I really enjoyed this stuff.
Bottle sampled with Steggosaurus. Pours hazy golden with a large white  head. Aroma of citrus,  fruit, smells like champange.  Flavor is carbonated, sour, and citrus. drinkable, but not enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2008 Light gold color, white head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma is corriander, yeast, citrus. Bubly, heavily carbonated "full" mouthfeel at first that dies down over time. Initial taste is spicy, really spicy, and tart with a citrusy and cleansing mid taste and finsh. The finish is also a bit tart. The tartness is great in combination with the style of beer. What a refreshing summer sipper and far from your "paint by numbers" typical wit beers. Thanks Tom.   Additional notes I was lucky enough  to pick up a six pack and I have noticed a few more things about the beer, first of all, it is rife with brett. Brett in the aroma, brett in the taste, brett everywhere. It is good, but this beer doesnt seem to be a wit anymore, it is more akin to a Ommegeddon. It is still very, very nice, but where is the balance?

Shared with csbosox.  Pours with a billowing white head atop hazy yellow/orange beer.  With lots of carbonation and good lace.  Tangy orange and lemon, with some peppery aromas.  There is some barrel character as well.  Orange tartness with some wood in the flavor.  It lingers on the back half of the tongue for a while.  Light, refreshing spritzy body.  Very nice.  It really hit the spot.

Thanks Santa!  Pours a cloudy yellow/golden with a huge soapy head that lasts for minutes.  Aroma is sour with hints of sweet oranges.  In the mouth its quite bitter and dry, a little watery and unsurprisingly quite carbonated.  I think that it achieves very well what the brewer was going for even though its not really to my taste.  Im glad I got the chance to sample it.

Poured an opaque golden color with a small thin frothy white head.  Not much retention.  Subtle aroma; citrus floral.  Light bodied, lots of carbonation.  Dry, sour grapefruit flavor, lightly spiced.  Very drinkable.  Good example of a Belgian White...not one of my favorite styles.
The aroma has an overall sour like consistency with notes of coriander and orange peel.  The pour is an orangish yellow with a white head and a sour like flavor with a slight citrusy bite.

12 oz bottle (sixth consumed of a six-pack), Bordeaux glass.  A giant, merangue-like foamy white head stands firmly on a light golden-amber body, cloudy from the addition of yeast.  Intoxicating waves of lemon, honey and graham cracker appear at first sniff.  Apricots, coriander, cloves and cracked pepper shortly follow.  Sour elements (reminds me of apple and banana baby foods) merge into a soft and well integrated oak note.  The aroma gives good indication of what the flavor will be like.  Starting creamy, softly acidic, fruity and buttery-oaky the front-end is nearly reminiscent of a California Chardonnay.  Mid-palate brings out a timid lemon sourness and leather and horseblanket funk.  The finish is tart and dry with strong grass, pepper and oak elements.  The mouthfeel is viscous enough to avoid watery, yet is soft enough to be palatable on a very hot day.  The explosive carbonation surely doesnt hurt in that regard, either.

So... this is what Brett tastes like? This poured a wonderful lemmon yellow with bubbly carbonated head, but the aroma and flavor were sort of frustrating- extremely sour, funky, yeasty. I can see the orange peel, but no coriander due to the overwhelming sourness. Finish is extremely dry... like champagne, but more sourness. Not as interesting as the other JP beer Ive tried.
Pours a golden hue with a thick white head.  Aromas of sour light yeast, funk and lemon.  Flavors of banana, yeast and funk.
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2007 Pours hazy gold into a tumbler.  Fluffy white medium-sized head with good retention.  Orange and lemon notes.  Brett upfront with a sour lemon dry finish.  Very refreshing.

Wow, refreshing, crisp. Id love to have this super fresh. Stil this is very good. Hints of the coriander, lemony, maybe a little more body or a little more effervescence/sparkle -- I could go either way -- but the body feels a tinge thin or flat. The general feelign was that this was a perfectly thirst quenching beer that could have been kicked up a notch by greater acidity, flavor and/or effervescence. Still a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2012 Great way to end a night of tasting.  This beer was a great witbier.  Poured a hazy cream color with some floaties.  Smelled of citrus and honey?  The taste was very sour with an unbelievably dry clean finish.  Amazing beer.  Thanks Jacob.

Re-rate 6.10.12

Wow. Much more sour than I remember. Almost Guezue sour. Worth a few more points I think.

750 mL bottle from artusory.  Pours a hazy pale straw yellow with a fizzy-frothy white head that quickly diminishes to a patchy film.  Aroma is yeast (earth, dough, cellar), citrus (orange zest), corriander and malt (grain, meal).  Orange zest and lemon tartness to start, medium acidity and bitterness, corriander, pepper, yeast, oak and malt (straw) flavors.  Medium to light bodied, fizzy and burpy, refreshing palate, lively carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of Thebeercellar2 : Pour a yellow ale with some white haze and a big foamy head with perfect retention. Aroma of brettanomyces was overly dominant and left little space for the coriander and orange peel that were advertised on the label. Taste is also dominated by the brettanomyces with some hints of coriander and wheat. Body is definitely above average for the style and that made it pretty enjoyable. Im not sure what to make of this beer since Im not sure the brett was planned to be there but it didnt stop my enjoyment of the beer.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, courtesy of Harry.  Dark yellow, small white head, tons of chunks.  Formidable aroma - like a wheat beer but kicked up quite a bit.  Spice, malt, and tons of yeast.  Lemon, yeast taste - soft, not spicy.  Strong like the aroma - a little sour too.  Not bad, I never quite got really in to it, but I enjoyed it.

Clear medium yellow body with a puffy white head.
Lemony aroma with some bread dough and a touch of Belgian funkyness.
Spritzy, with some tartness. Sweetness that fades seamlessly into a lingering dryness.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a clear very pale yellow with a spare diminishing frothy white head. Aroma of fruit, lots of spice, citrus, yeast and a mild funkyness. Spicy, citrusy flavour with some yeast and sourness -- gets a little "geuze"-like after it warms a little. Light to medium bodied, nicely carbonated. Good stuff, I quite enjoyed it.

Tap.  Aroma:  Lemon, coriander, sourdough bread, and a chemical aroma that I couldnt place (almost like cough syrup).  Appearance:  Watched the bartender pour this one.  Came out of the tap very foamy, but eventually settled down.  Hazy lemon meringue pie yellow with a bright white evervescent head.  Head lingered for quite awhile.  Good lacing throughout.  Flavor:  Tart lemon flavor followed by a bevy of spices (corinader, cloves, szechuan pepper).  A delicate malt sweetness was the foundation for all these other flavors.  Also detected notes of hay and grass.  Palate:  light to medium bodied.  Seemed a bit drier than many other witbiers Ive tried, which I enjoyed.  Carbonation was lively and prickly on the tongue.  Finish seemed a little watery to me.  Overall:  An enjoyable beer that a beer newbie could pick up and enjoy, but with enough depth to make it interesting.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2006 Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle.  Poured murky yellow with a small white head, huge dark chunks in the bottom.  Wonderful aroma - funky, sour, very spicy, lemon juice - coriander and orange zest; sharp, almost eye-watering.  Sharply spicy and yeasty, lemon sourness, malt lurking, the coriander and the lemon really take the drivers seat.  Acidic, sharply lively bitter mouthfeel, very funky, spicy and complex - excellent beer, quite a shift from the Midnight Sun M that preceeded it!

750ml - Aroma of yeast, candi sugar, bananna, orange peel, and coriander.  Pours transparent yellow with a huge lasting head from the constantly cascading champange like bubbles and great lacing.  Flavor matches the aroma with the spiciness really taking over as it warms.  Palate is sticky and tart.  Interesting and tasty.

After being slightly disappointed with the Bam Biere, I decided to open this one.  It was 95 here today, and I was outside most of the day, so once this one was very cold, I opened it up.  Pours out with a giant head, with chunks of shit floating all down through it.  Fear not, it does not four up the flavor of this beer.  Smells fruity, with a nice smell of oranges and some oak.  Taste is very similar, and very refreshing.  Much more complex than say...Hoegaarden is.  This beer definately makes the brewery stand out, as any brewery that makes a really good solid Witbier gets my vote.  Really great beer, and worth trying at any cost.

Light to dark yellow color with a big bountiful head.  Sweet spicy aroma almost pasta like.  Fruity in the flavor, some hints of lemon, has a nice wheat character to it. A little tart but ends up with a nice dry finish. My first jolly pumpkin very interesting

Poured a light straw color with a very slight haze and a fluffy tight white head.  Aroma has a very wheaty, hay-field character, with lots of lemon.  Flavor is lemon, with mint, and sourdough.  Mouthfeel is crisp, dry and tart.  What I really enjoy about Jolly Pumpkin ales are the brettanomyces chraracter that leaves and interesting depth to their beers.  This would go well with white fleshed pan sheared fish or under the shade of a tree on a warm summers evening.

Delicious aroma, very enticing, dried flowers and fresh cut wheat stalks, with a spicy citrus zing in the flavor, and some nice toasted malt, clean and very dry, with some nice fruitiness, and yeasty esthers.  Still has that JP sour flavor, with evident corriander zest.  Definitely worth trying.

It had a thin, fizzy head and a body that was way too translucent for a witbier.  It is quite dry but the aroma is just not the spice and citrus that a good wit should be.  Agree that its closer to a saison than a witbier.  Not what I was expecting out of a top ten wit for this site.

Bottle.  Sour, musty wheat aroma.  Light yellow with giant head and high effervescence.  Light dry orange and musty flavor with spice tones in the finish - coriander and vanilla.  Probably the driest witbier available - tastewise closer to a saison or lambic.  A very nice tasting beer but if youre expecting a taste like Hoegaarden, youre going to be disappointed.

12oz. Bottle. Multiple aromas of spice, banana, vanilla and mustard. Cloudy yellow body with creamy head. Vanilla and banana flavor with spices in the background. Smooth on the palate and leves some light spice and vanilla aftertaste. Good brew suprised to see Jolly Pumkin in 12 oz. bottles in AZ.

Ok, this one didnt impress me. Poured a bit too clear of a golden yellow color with a very thin head and near to none lacing. The aroma was tart and lemon-like. The flavor was all funky lemon tart, coriander/spices underplayed. Tasted like a Berliner Weisse (but with more tart than lactic acids) crossed with Martens Madonna. The mouthfeel was thin, lightly carbonated.
A spicy lemon aroma. The flavor is rather sour and dusty with a mix of some mouth pukering citrus fruit. The mouthfeel is rather dry. Pretty good wit beer.

Bottle sampled with Beerded-one. Pours hazy golden with a huge fluffly white lasting head. Aroma of citrus, fermented fruit, champange like nose. Flavor is carbonated, sour, citrusy, not my thing, i wasnt into this as much as I originally thought I would be. Reminded me of an unblended lambic (Cantillon Iris)

Champagne bottle. Fantastic label. Pours a comically enormous white head with a beautiful bright yellow/straw body. The attack, mid-palate, and finish are all viciously tart, overwhelmingly cherried. This is a beautifully done statement that is simply too far down the path for me. The tartness renders everything else secondary, and thats imbalance.

Sampled at Broudys Beerfest, Jacksonville FL, 3 June 2006.   One of the more interesting and enjoyable beers sampled.  Complex wit flavor with coriander, yeasty and spicy. Slightly dry and tart.  Well balanced.  Excellent wit.
Poured pale yellow with a light frothy head.  Nose of tart citrus and mild belgian esthers, some vanilla as well.  Mouth was tart but balanced for this style.  Quite good.
Thanks to chilehead for sharing this bottle. Snowy froth over pale yellow, light fruity spicy aroma. Crisp and slightly tart, a very drinkable balanced Wit, well done.

Bottle from Archer Liquors. Pours with a big, fizzy white head that doesnt lace. Lots of dark brown yeast chunks floating around. Flavor is interestingly orangy, slightly spicy, dry, and very lactic. It is acidic underneath the strong fruit tones of orange and banana, lime. The nose has a lot more spice. There is a fair amount of oak and husky wheat.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2007 Bottle.  Pours cloudy light golden with a huge bubbly head, vigorous carbonation, and a few small yeast chunks.  Aroma isnt too strong, but is of citrus, coriander, yeast, and possibly pine hops; a bit sour.  Flavor is dry and tart, dominated by spices, yeast, and a general mild sourness.  Quite interesting and a bit intense; definitely not the refreshing summers day session beer that many witbiers are.  Not exactly to my tastes, but interesting nonetheless.

Traditional hazy light gold color with a large fluffy white head, small yeast chunks.  Spciy yeast aroma: coriander, orange.  Lots of carbonation with a dry finish.  A big plus going to the 12oz bottle as I do not think this style translates well to a large bottle due to the bottom yeast.
Big white head.  Smells of citrus and spice.  Orange and coriander.  Tastes more of the coriander.  A little dry and sour.  Reminds me of a geueze on the back end.

12 ounce bottle poured into a snifter.  A bubbly white head formed on top of a straw gold liquid. The head diminished quickly and left no lacing on the glass.  This really needed to warm up (from 44 degrees) to even get the faintest aroma.  That aroma was light citrus hop and maybe if I stretch it some spices.  The flavor was faint too.  Probably b/c this is such a highly carbonated brew.  Kind of reminds me of their Bam Bier only watered down in aroma and flavor.

Pours very light golden with a huge foamy white head. Aroma of chamomile, coriander, and notes of citrus herbs. Taste is quite strong with chamomile and the other spices, making this beer too spicy for my palette. Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with a slight resinous quality.  I didnt enjoy this beer very much, but I wouldnt say this is a bad beer. A bit overspiced or underaged.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2007 12 Oz Bottle. Gusher! Incredibly. The bottle just keeps flowing. Im surprised this wasnt a bottle bomb. Light sweet brett notes and nip of apple skins, pear reduction and sherry. Tangy. Pours a hazed lemon skin yellow, with a rocky head of too much. Flavor is a lemon juice and gin sour sweet flavor, with plenty of aged apple juice, bready wheat malt and copious spicy, sticky yeast notes. A faint glow of alcohol caresses a grainy smack. Light hop tinglings meld with the sour notes. Crisp, refreshing and brightly drinkable. An interesting run on a Wit.

The aroma had light fermented fruit, flowers, very light citrus, and coriander.  The beer poured a yellow color with gold highlights, thin lasting head and lacing.  The flavor had coriander, cloves, fermented light fruit, light malts and citrus.  The mouthfeel was light and creamy.
This beer to me was umimpressive. I got a sense of a soapy taste to it. I really like the way it pour and gave off an impressive head , sadly the beer is less than desireble

I am impressed . Always thought of a Belgian Wit as a light womans session brew,this brew was actually bold and intense. Lots of lemony Belgian lemony yeast ester aroma, ,classic light whitish  color,very spicey orangy but light taste,had a wonderful perkiness to it,with the corriander finish. An amazing example of what a good brewer can to with a typically mondane style. Thanks Chris of Murrays in Whitefish Bay

Pours a hazed yellow with a sandy head. The aroma is full of citrus, although almost more lemony than orange. Coriander is there as well has a heavy phenolic perfume. This isnt really what I was expecting. Dry and heavy carbonation. A very interesting take on the witbier style.

Cloudy yellow pour with a huge white head and nice lacing.  Aroma is primarily wheat, yeast and orange.  Lots of carbonation in the mouthfeel department.  Very tart as advertised, a bit sour almost. Has a very fruity character in addition to the corriander.   Nice dry, spicy finish.  Pretty good.
I really like Belgian White Ales and this one did not dissappoint.This beer was a nice balance of flavors and very refreshing.
I not a big fan of White Ales. However I enjoyed this greatly. Great beers come from small breweries. Perfect for the spring season.  Delicious. Too bad all white ales arent as good as this.
An elegant, lithe beer.  It has an almost champagne-like effervescence.  Very nice.
clear yellow with a nice frizzy white head.nice fruity aromatic aroma.the flavor was a wonderful mix of sour,spice,carbonation,and malt.this is a nice balance of fruity,spicey,and sour.

Nose of orange, perfume, vinegar, cereal, flowers, lemon zest, and apricots.  Pours a
sparkling honey straw with melon highlights.  The large frothy white head is fully lasting
with light lace.  The fruity flavor is mostly sour with heavy acidity.  The finish has a tart
malt character.  The watery body is fizzy and dry.
Poured pale yellow with a foamy white head.  Nice appearance.  Smelled like corriander, orange, lemon and spice.  Taste was way too sour for me.  Bad bottle perhaps.

bottle pours a sickly pale yellow with a huge foamy white head. aroma is orange peel, yeasty a litttle funk and spice. taste is mellow with slight funk up front with a bit of malt, spice and orange following it up. not bad

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale golden coloured body with a huge frothy white head. Funky aroma - cheesy and oaky yeast with a good dose of lemon zest and pears. Similar to a typical Wit but then you have the JP twist of tart funkiness. Soft creamy yeast mouthfeel with lots of fruity flavour. Mild sweetness up front then leading into some citric lemony finish with some soapiness. Pretty good and interesting. 

Purchased at The Beer Depot, Ann Arbor in February 2006.

Poured a hazy golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of earthy yeast, spices, citrus, orange peel, and some grassy hops.  Taste was quite sour, grapes, green apple, more citrus, that was tart and acidic.  Medium carbonation.

Pours a lightly hazy golden yellow with a small bubbly white head.  Aroma of spices, wheat, barnyard, lemon coriander, some orange and vanilla.  Flavor was more of the wheat, slightly tart and tingly carbonation.  Was also picking up some of the wood in the aroma and flavor.

Hazy straw yellow with a huge rocky white head. Spicy aroma, coriander, lemon. The lemon flavor dominates the flavor here, though it could just be this bottle is past its prime. Thin and watery at times as well.

Pour is hazy deep dark yellow with a big bubbled fast fading off white head...definate funky aroma...tart and citric yet yeasty and horseblankety...taste is very dry...some oak, some tart flavors but definately spicy and warm at first...lots of malty citrus flavors, finish tart and sour...very very interesting and unique...

Lambic, wild-yeast aroma, reminiscent of a gueuze. Carbonated, lively mouthfeel, almost like champagne. No Belgian lacing whatsoever in this beer. Immediate flavor is citrus, fades to sour yeast, and leaves an almost tannic dryness on finish. Its short aftertaste with sparkling acidity makes this a refreshing beer. Its a different take on the witbier. Think witbier meets saison.

From the bottle.

Pours a hazy straw-gold with an ambitious white head. The aroma is sour yeasts and a bit of orange and candy-shop and hint of coconut and nutmeg. On the tongue, the beer is surprisingly sour and rustic, almost heading into saison territory. Lemon juice dominates the flavor early, spiced up by belgian witbeer yeasts and ginger and again the coconut with a nice and impressively bitter grassy-hop finish that only appears very late in the sip. The palate is sparkling and refreshing.

This my first taste of Jolly Pumpkins wares, and Im impressed. This is a very nice take on a belgian witbeer.

Still has that ridiculous sour aroma.  Ive never seen a more carbonated beer.  I thought the glass was going to explode.  Flavor is a watered down Bam Biere which is good because that beer is horribly bad.  This has the same sour vinegar taste.  Doesnt taste at all like witbier.  again, not that bad because its not as intensely gross as the Bam Biere.

looks pretty dumb.  very effervescent, which is cool, but the head lacks personality and the color is a little close to high life.  also, i accidentally poured the bottom of the bottle into the glass several minutes later - big mistake.  enormous ugly brown/red chunks of yeast.  smells and tastes like JPs.  RealLime lime juice flavor into the finish, huge sourness.  smells pretty appetizing though.  far from my favorite wit, sorry drew.

750 mL bottle.  Pours cloudy yellow with a way-too-overactive head.  Theres really not much in the aroma.  Maybe a slight mustiness and a little bit of citrus.  First sip .. wow!  Thats one tart mutha.  The label says its brewed with orange peel.  You can say that again.  Way too much orange peel if you ask me.  Very tart (bordering on sour) and bretty.  Now, normally, I love to have a bit of brettanomyce in my beer, but it doesnt jive well with this one.  I also didnt get a hint of spices in this.  This one is different from any other wit out there, but Im not sold on it.
Cloudy blond color. Citrusy aroma (lemon). Thin body, light wheat character, citrusy, dry, very light astringency. Correct bitterness.

Thanks to Zuchinincat for sharing. Pours a very cloudy light straw with a pillowy white head that lasts. Aroma is acidic with light notes of traditional spicing. The body is light, effervescent and refreshing, but not that mouth-filling. The flavor is innitially tart...like gueze tart but it melds into a funky fruitiness with notes of orange and lemon. The finish is exceedingly dry. This is a perfect summer thirst quencher.

750 mL bottle.  Poured a pale, hazy golden with a towering, creamy white head.  Nose was wonderfully tart and funky, with coriander spiciness, lemongrass, and orange zest.  Flavor was a tart and sour assault on the palate.. stronger and more complex than any witbier Ive tried.  Lemon and orange zest were spritzy with a sour barnyard/yeast/Brett complement.  White pepper and coriander left a lasting spicy impression... along with citrus and cellar.    Excellent and exciting brew!

Pours a hazy straw with a gigantic fluffy white head.  Aroma of sour yeast, coriander, lemon, orange, and some barn.  Spices are not very present in this brew.  Fairly sour in the taste, otherwise following the aroma pretty well.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 750 ml bottle poured a clearpale yellow with a large creamy long lasting white head. Aromas of sour orange and spices. Palate was light bodied. Flavors of tart citrus, pepper and cloves with a crisp refreshing tart finish. Possibly the best wit beer Ive tasted!

Quite a different witbier.  Looks and pours like Hoegaarden (and my homebrew wit), that is, cloudy, pale yellow with a bright, white head.  The aroma is some else, though.  More orange peel odor than Ive noticed in other whites, and indescribably spicy.  Huge spice flavor, almost peppery.  Very citrusy.  Slight clove aftertaste.  A bit more bitterness than in other whites, but still pleasant-- enough to balance the tartness from the citrus.  Thin-medium body, typical for a wit.  An enjoyable beer.

From bottle.  Hazy, banana yellow gold pour with a tall, soapy white head.  Clean, refreshing aroma of light fruits and spice.  Delicate, supple bouquet of banana and creamy vanilla, along with some light orange spice.  Very upfront, sour tart flavors of lemon zest and a mild, even coriander spice.  I like the lambic-like dimensions that initially grab my attention; its especially interesting how the tartness gives way to a clean, yeasty smooth finish.  Overall, a unique and delicately flavored brew whose real character and personality comes from the variety of sensory dimensions it excites, rather than the number of fruit or yeast levels it presents.  Thanks, Tom!

Poured a hazy light gold with a medium fluffy white head.  Aroma was tart/citrusy with yeasty funk and some spiced notes on the finish.  Tart fruity flavor.  Semi-dry spiced finish.  Malty in the middle.  Lively and fizzy mouthfeel.

Hazy gold, with huge frothy head.  Spicy aroma.  More spicy than orangey, plenty tart and dare I say wild aroma.  Some dirty coriander.  Medium to light body.  Full-on brett character melds well blend quite well with orangey citrus, much as orvals brett character goes sublimely with the orange rindy styrians.  Some bitterness, but it seems more from orange than from hops, or are there styrians here as well?  This is quite excellent.  Remove the coriander (which in this beer more than other wits I only find distracting) and you have yourself a lighter beer with the personality of Orval, and thats no small compliment.

I know its very subjective, but this bottle has one of my favorite labels.  the color is a cloudy yellow gold, with a tall creamy off-white head.  aroma is brett, yeasty, sweet coriander.  flavor is tart meyer lemon, dried orange peel, zesty and white pepper.  dryish but not too bitter.  crisp with lively carbonation.  JP does a great job of keeping the character in all their beers down to the lightest ones they brew.  I really like to see some brett in the midwest!

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2008 thanks to northerntimber for the brew...a bit of a gusher...very attenuated.   Pours a pale clover honey with a massive dirty cream colored head.  Aroma is huge brett,tart yeast funk, and citurs.  Flavor is very citrusy...both sweet and tart (lemons and grapefruit), oily citrus zest, a bit of dry peppery flavor, an interesting malt profile for a witbier...and some hoppy dryness.  Mouthfeel is lightly carbonated, but very lively.  As the description suggests...this beer is very...no, extremely refreshing.  This is the best belgian wit Ive had...perhaps not the most in style...but best suited for my current tastes and mood.  Damn I like this.
""Ho hum Poured a light golden color with almost no head. Aroma was of lemons. Flavor had a funky lemon taste to it, and i am not a lemon fan so this one didnt go over well with me. "

Slightly hazy, pale gold appearance.  Small white, fast fading head left little lacing.  Yeasty aroma; lemon much  more apparent as it warmed to cellar temperatures.  Cant dismiss the orange peel.  Medium-to-light body with lots of carbonation.  Tart, dry, citrusy, spicy taste.  Dry, peppery, short lived finish.

Hazy and bright yellow with a big loose white head. Zesty, yeasty citrus and corriander aroma. Light and carbonated with a pronounced bitterness that lingers on the tongue. I swear this is from the orange peel though others tell me that bitter orange adds no perceptable bitterness. It has a delicate lemon/orange and corriander flavor. Drier, sharper and more effervescent than many Witbiers. Better than most.

Barrel Draught from the jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 29/09/2005
Golden coloured with a hazy appearance. Some alcohol present. Crisp on the palate. Slightly fruity banana flavour. Hint of dryness in the finish.

Pours a clear golden, with an extremely frothy head the entire time. I was holding on to this for a while thinking it may have been the best beligian white my favorite style beer I have ever had with all the hype on the brewer, but it definitely wasnt even close. Dominant flavors are coriander and orange peel the whole time, along with a slight lemony aftertaste and maybe a ever so slight hint of banana, other than that it leaves a very poor taste in your mouth that does not taste good at all, I dont hate it but know I will never buy this again at $7, very dissapointing.

Perfumy, lavender nose. Hazy pale orange color, fluffy head. Real citrusy, lemon and orange. Sweet in the middle. Puckering, lactic yeasty end. Light spice. Leaves sweet dollop on the lips like a fruit juice. Medium body, creamy texture. Unusual and interesting.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2007 Bottle:  Cloudy deep yellow with a large small-bubbled white head, orange peel and spices in the aroma with a touch of lemon, starts and ends lightly sweet with some sourness, light mouthfeel with prickly carbonation.

Cloudy, golden body with a medium sized white head that fades to a cover. Big juicy orange aroma with notes of spice, pineapple and musty notes. Refreshingly tart, orange, pineapple, corriander and cobwebs. Mouthfeel is light and lively. Dry finish. Not really true to style, but JP brews to their own style. The use of Brett, in my opinion, is much more interesting than the usual banana and clove of the Hoegaarden yeast. Also the spicing of this beer is just right, too many brewers over spicing their Wits. This was nice and refreshing. Another winner from JP.

750 ml champagne style bottle. Crowned, but not corked. No freshness date seen anywhere. Poured out a pale golden yellow color, with an effervescent meringue head. The head settled back to a thin lacing on top of the beer. Aromas are of coriander, citrus peel, mostly lemon. Includes a tart Granny Smith apple character as well. Flavors are of Granny Smith apples right off the bat. Some Brettanomyces is also present, probably from the barrel aging. Lively on the tongue, spritely. Thin body & mouthfeel. Crisp flavors fade quickly off the tongue. A decent Witbier from JP.

An unclear yellow beer with a disappearing white head. The aroma is sweet spicy - with ginger being quite strong. The flavor is very carbonated with notes of spices - again strong notes of ginger, but also lesser notes of coriander, leading to a dry end. Less carbonation would do this beer good.

Pours a cloudy light dirty yellow, with white head. Citrus, grape, and light spice nose. The taste is a spicy light citrus. Grapefruit comes through as does the coriander. Very light, bubbly mouthfeel.

One of my favorites at the Beerfest 2006 in Ybor City; I will be having more of this. The aroma and flavor are what you would expect from the style yet it also has some unique qualities. It is much fruitier than I was expecting.

Hazy yellow body with a monstrous head. Aroma is spices, oranges, lemons and a hint of oak. Flavor is the same, VERY tart for a Witbier. Slightly watery body, definitely not a normal Wit. More interesting than good.
Hazy orange color with a medium white, creamy, average lasting head. Nice orange and wheat nose. Mandarin, kumquats and yeast taste with lots of koriander - YUMMY. Very refreshing - I love it!

750 ml bottle:  Pours a clear golden yellow hue.  Small sticky white head is mostly lasting.  Sweet orange nose, grain, faint spice.  Steady carbonation, grainy, bread, spice, bland citrus.  Sweet, overly sweet after a while.  Not too impressed.  Turd Fergusen is a bastard.

from a 750ml. hazy golden in color with a big white head. citrus dominates aroma with some spice wheat and a little yeast. balanced sweet and tart citrus flavor. very very carbonated. very fizzy and refreshing but the carbonation might be a bit too much. very light body. one of the better wheat beers i have had.

750mL bottle.  Pours a hazy gold with a thick and fizzy off-white head that lingers.  Tart, wheaty and citrusy aroma.  Lots of lemons in there.  Coriander and oranges are apparent as it warms.  Crisp and thin with a high level of carbonation that gets quite distracting.  A VERY tart beer.  Wheaty and yeasty with plenty of lemons and oranges thoughout.  A hint of coriander.  Crisp, clean finish.  This was so tart that my girlfriend thought it was infected.  I can only assume that its not.

From a bottle shared by Chuck.  Yellow body with intense carbonation suspending a fluffy white head.  Sulphury aroma - pear skin, sulphur, a patch of soured malt. The sulphur that I couldnt get away from in the aroma disappears once you sip.  Its replaced by lactic grapefruit rind and lightly toasted saltine.  Some coriander and floral elements.  I like the brett addition to this wit.

Pours a light straw color very light heavy carbonation visable and a full frothy white head.  almost a light sulfer in the aroma.. lots of lemon and citurs rind notes corriander light peppers, potentailly even a hint of leather.  Nice carbonation even feel.  Flavor is a lightly sour citrus hints of lemon rinds light grains and some perfume hop.  A very good witbier.

from the bottle. poured a cloudy yellow with a big white head that left a lot of lacing. aroma, wheat , lemon, sweet orange, when it warms up a little some sourness comes out. flavor first impression very light  and refreshing, lemon, wheat, citrus, sugar. a nice dry finish.second impression very light and a very easy drinking beer. this went very well with my shrimp stir fry.will get more of this.

750ml Bottle thanks to Styles: Pours to a beautiful bright and pale yellow, mostly opaque even with held to the light, with an enormous frothy white head that lasts throughout the entire glass.  Very miniscule bubbles can be seen gently rising to the surface.  A touch of mild lemongrass and wheat rise to meet the nose, followed by citrus, coriander, fresh orange rind (almost unripened), a hint of pepper, musty hay-filled sack, light nutmeg, spices, and gentle wood.  The flavors unfold with a brief lemongrass, followed immediately by a slightly tart wheat and light citrus that is very refreshing to the palate.  The orange rind comes through towards the middle, and definitely more after a few successive sips, there may even be a slight hint of grapefruit rind here too.  The spicy yeast, coriander, and hints of pepper come out towards the end, but are quickly replaced by a quick retronasal hop note, then moderately dry wheat, and dusty hay at the finish.  Medium bodied, excellent natural carbonation, tiny, well-integrated bubbles tingle and create a filling but not heavy feeling.  It does seem to be just a bit on the tart side, and maybe a bit hoppy, with more oak (dry white wine-like barrel?) than Im used to tasting, but it is well-integrated into the whole beer.  Very nice.
Golden but not very hazy....huge white head of suds...perfect looking really...standard orange and coriander..kind of dry actually..with almost a tropical white wine taste mixed in there

(750 ml bottle: Obtained in trade with Eyedrinkale, thanks Mike!) Big, frothy, white head takes quite some time to settle out, thanks in part to the army of carbonation bubbles that rise at break-neck speed to the surface.  But as it does settle, a thick, foamy curtain of lace coats the entire glass and shows exceptional longevity.  Lots of coriander and citrus in the nose.  Wheat, yeast, mild lemony citrus, coriander, gently bitter orange peel, all present and all wonderfully balanced.  Not really all that tart to me, but its not even mildly sweet.  Body is light-medium and carbonation is lively but not expansive.  With the spices, citrus and carbonation, this beer is very refreshing on the palate.  Bright golden yellow, only somewhat cloudy until the final pour when a significant amount of sediment finally flows into my glass.  Heading, retention and lacing remain visually stunning for the entire session, and Ive dragged this session out for nearly three hours (so the beer is certainly at room temperature).  A well-made witbier, certainly one of the more balanced American-made witbiers Ive sampled.  Nice job.

(750ml Bottle) This beer is light and sharply acidic, which makes for one dry and complex brew. Freshly ground coriander emanates from the beers thick foam. Citric acid both in the lemon and orange variety make this concoction electric. Dry as a bone, that pretty much sums up the finish. This beer is pretty damn good, kind of like a cross between a wit and a lambic.
Lemony gold color with a nice rocky white head. Spicy, wheaty, citrus aroma.  Grassy flavor is light, spritzy and slightly tart.  Very easy to drink. Clean and well carbonated.
Pours with a massive head, lovely citrus aroma.  Fairly thin mouthfeel, VERY sour citrus flavor.  I usually like Whites, but this one is far too sour for me.

Pours unclear golden and a frothy white head. Full aroma of yeast, orange and citrus with a slight tone of alcohol (!). Wheat and yeast flavor with lots of fruit in there as well. White pepper notes. Flat mouthfeel. Rather unbalanced, but interesting.
Rating # 2200. Hazy pale yellow colour with a fast disappearing white head. Yeasty and spicy aroma with a light fruity note. Sweet and yeasty flavor with a fruity note and a floral finish.
Bottle. Hazy pale golden colour. White head. Aroma is spicy with hints of yeast and coriander. Flavor is much the same as aroma, but also hints of citrus. Has a spicy finish.
Bottle. Light hazy golden colour with a white head. Fruity, spicy aroma and taste. Medium body with a light perfumed finish.

(Bottle 75 cl) Pours an unclear, pale golden with a rather tall, white head. Aroma of yeast, citrus and coriander. Rather light-bodied with plenty of fresh fruit, but quite a different fruit profile than in your typical Belgian Wit. Perhaps a wee accent of coconut? Very fresh, would be the perfect summer quencher. 270106
Pours a hazy yellow with a white head. Sweet and fruity. Aromas of abricot, citrus and some spicyness. Sticky mouthfeel. Could have a smoother CO2 profile. Long fruity and peppery finish.

Bottle.
Clear yellow coloured with a white head.
Aroma of citrus with notes of fruits and spices.
Sweet flavour of citrus with notes of fruits and spices.

Bottled (Courtesy of BBB63 - thanks): Golden coloured. Light hazy. Fluffy off white head. Fruit, spices and yeast in the nose. Quite subtle aromas. Fruits, sweetness and light grassy notes in the flavour. Is somehow grapish and light sour. Has a spicy touch. Is grapish and light sour in the end. Quite refreshing. Listening to the beer is like standing on the waterfront on a calm evening with the waves silently splashing on the brink. Nice.

bottle-pours nice hazy neon yellow with a small fizzy white head with a nice level of fuzzy carbonation.  big orange peal aroma with some of that oak/beachwood coming through.  complex spicy flavors with corriander, oak, lemons, hay, but really doesnt taste like any other wit i have ever had.  the oak comes through more as it warms, creating a very woodsy note.  very complex for such a low abv beer.  I will have to rerate this one with a full bottle (i only got one sample).

Pours a hazy pale golden color with an almost Duvel sized white head that fades agonizingly slow. Theres a thick rocky cap left that leaves as well as tons of lacing after the head fades. Impressive.

Smell; slightly sweet to start, with some lemon and orange zest. Theres a bit of a peppery spiciness with some vanilla, and just a hint of hay.

Taste; initiialy the citric flavors really stand out with the lemon and orange. After a few sips a bit of vanilla and a woody presence show up, with a nice drying spiciness in the finish. Mouthfeel is nice and crisp, with plenty of carbonation. This is one refreshing beer that is very easy to drink.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Bottle, from Julios. Sharp yeasty. Lemon, corriander, I thought I was getting a corn thing, maybe it was the yeast. I dont know. Clean yellowy gold color, nice head and lacing. Soft tart flavor, like aroma. Lemon in the forefront, spice too. Medium body, lite crisp mouthfeel, bitter lemony mouthfeel. Kind of nice, easy to drink, Im just not a witbier kind of beer drinker.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Big thanks to TAR for this one!  Very hazy medium yellow, great soft, pillowy head.  Aroma was coriander spice and lemon.  Flavor was very lemony, with balancing, not bitter coriander.  Finish was a big surprise, very, very tart.  Id almost think something a bit bacterial was going on here.  Very enjoyable, and the sour finish was a refreshing and unique take on the style.

Cloudy yellow pour with attractive white, foamy head. Spicy aroma and flavor with hints of wheat. Notes of coriander, clove, nutmeg and cinamon. A bit of banana is hidden below the spice. Thin body and crisp finish.
Light yellow with champagne like bubbles.  Yeasty, earthy aroma is also slightly fruity.  The body is good, but thin.  Mostly apple throughout.  Just OK.

750 ml bottle.  Sparkling golden yellow on the pour with a large, long lasting head.  Scents of citrus and wheat on the nose.  Refreshing tart citrus flavors with banana and spice in the back.  Ending with a dry finish. Very nice.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2007 Tangerine Coloring with White Head.  Wheaty and Yeasty Notes on the Nose....Bit of the Same on the Tongue...Along With a Overripe Banana Flavor...Coriander Tastes Past its Prime as Well. Overall a bit Stale.

Rerated 4-9-07:  Light Hazed Yellow. Light Ctirus Aroma.  Coriander and Citrus Notes..Sweet Malt Flavor..Dry Bittering Aftertaste. Almost a Vegetable Bitter Feel to It.   Certainly an Interesting Take on a White, but Perhaps a Love it or Hate it Take.
Straw colored, cloudy, with a white head. Some banana sweetness and cloves in the nose. Flavor is medium sweet, unpleasantly sulphury, with some banana and bitterness.

This bottled brew poured a medium sized head of foamy fine to medium sized mostly lasting white colored bubbles that left behind a good lacing.  The body contained average carbonation, was slightly hazy and yellow in color.  Its aroma contained notes of mild malt floral .  Its mouth feel is initially tingly crisp mild bubbly hop malt with a lingering  tingly clean crisp palate.  Its flavor contained malty hoppy grassy notes and was tasty.  A nice brew indeed.  Good to see Jolly Pumpkin still making decent beers!.

Light yellow in color with a very lively bubbly head. Aroma was citrisy with lots of herbal and flowery notes following up with some spice. Flavor was spicey with plenty of lemon and orange finishing tart and peppery. Lots of carbonation in the mouth with a light body. Very flavorful and very champagne like. I thought it was very enjoyable and may even attempt to make mamosas with it.

Hazy gold amber color. Large white foamy head. Aroma is tart, citrusy and spicy. Medium bodied wit. Malts are fruity and sweet. Orange peel, coriander and some orange/citrus. Lively carbonation. Nice wit. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly sweet. Thanks to Dr Bill for sharing this one.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2006 750ml bottle

I am rerating this primarily for my own reference, even though the original
   rating was not that bad.  Coming back to this reminds me why Jolly Pumpkin
   is a rising star in the beer world - as long as this is one of their average
   beers, they are among the best in the country.  Track it down if you can and
   you wont be disappointed.
Aroma / Appearance - Hints of orange peels, lemons, wheat, honey and
   hay wafted up into my eager nose in a nice balance.  The body itself was about
   the color of liquid mandarin oranges minus the pulp.  A one-finger head
   lingered briefly before being consumed by the body.  Overall, it was very
   inviting with no faults.
Flavor / Palate - A peppery carbonation is the immediate response to
   a first sip, followed by oranges, limes, wheat, vanilla and peaches.  A smooth
   buttery texture underlies everything ever so slightly as overall it reminds
   me of day old champagne.  The finish is clean, dry and leaves traces of orange
   on the throat.  An exceptionally well done Belgian from one of the finest
