   producers of Belgian style beers in the US.

12.04.05  750ml bottle at HW open house, thanks to Dorwart for bringing this beauty!  Cloudy yellow-white pour the color of stained teeth; the head is lofty and fizzy, loose, and white.  The aroma is a burst of yummy JP funk with lemon and oak plus plenty of wheat.  A dry and stark palate, this sort of beer begs to be guzzled in a plea for quenching.  Spices meld well with yeast and hint of brett.

Aroma of orange, coriander and a hint of brett-barnyard, but not too strong.  Cloudy, straw-yellow flavor with a nice white head.  Flavor is a spicy orange, spicy coriander with some black pepper.  Coriander is very fresh and bright.  Watery texture with a tart, dry finish.  Not much barnyard in the flavor at all.  Very enjoyable.

Pours with that unfiltered hazy pale yellow look like most white ales....whoa, a big pillowy white head formed.  Aroma is all about spiciness with some yeast and hops to boot.  Flavor is more of the same with a tinge of coriander and orange zest.  A lingering bitterness accompanies the nice maltiness too.  Fuller than expected mouthfeel.  A very nice white ale.

750ml bottle.This is the best witbier Ive had yet, though it defeats Lake Louie Prairie Moon for that title by a technicality: Prairie Moon is called a "farmhous ale" by the brewery and classified here as a saison even though it has all the characteristics of a witbier: light straw color, unfiltered yeast haze, coriander and orange peel. But I digress -- back to the Jolly Pumpkin.

Hazy light straw-colored pour with a huge fluffy white head that grudgingly agrees to settle down to half an inch where it remains in perpetuity or until you drink the last drop, whichever comes first. Spectacular witbier aroma -- spicy hops, coriander, citrus/orange peel, and more spicy hops. Coriander takes center stage in the flavor, suppored by that big hop spice, light hop bitterness, orange peel, and light sugary malt. Medium body (actually a bit heavy for the style), fizzy palate with a long citrus aftertaste. Quite a remarkable witbier. This is one Ill buy again and again.

Hazy amber body beneath a fizzy white head.  The aroma is tart, lemon and orange zest, a little hot spice, ginger, clove, malt and yeast.  Light/medium body with lively carbonation and a creamy feel.  The flavor was semi-sweet, cirtus tart, spicy.  Not bad.

Nice combination of spicey refreshment and tart appetizing zest. Orange peel is prominent with some Lactic and Pedio. hints. Soft mouthfeel that is round and full. Slightly hoppy and effervescent finish. Very nice beer that is more than just a white ale. Had at celebrator tasting.

Pours a very nice hazy yellow with a creamy white head.  Aromas of coriander, oranges and some sugar rise from the grass with bananas and oak in the wake.  Taste is not as grand, unfortunately but still pleasant with nice coriander and citrus elements.  Finish is on the light end, but overall this would make an excellent session beer in the summer.
Hazy yellow with a big white head. Aroma of yeast and spices. Flavor is pretty tart, with spices and yeast.

pours out a hazy yellow with bubbly head.  Aroma of yeast, light fruit, corriander.  Flavor incorporates the wood, as well as the orange peel and mix em together to make up a nice refreshing tasting witbier.

Hazy,golden with a big,fluffy,head that settles. Aroma is large on the coriander,but the malt,cookie,and spicy,yeast presence is there as well.  Body is substantial,and moderately,carbonated.  Flavors of the wood,yeast,malt are all well integrated,and the hops balance in with these perfectly. The finish is my favorite part of the beer,starting spicy,and hoppy,but with a lingering,dough,malt flavor.A fav in a style I usually dont care for.
Bottle. Thanks Mike. Golden clear yellow in color with a nice fluffy white head. Spicey aroma with notes of coriander. Tart. Flavor is spicey. Refreshing. Finish is dry. Drinkable and enjoyable.

cloudy infected looking dark yellow pour with a lasting white head. aroma is pound cake with a moonshine taste. biting earthy flavor with vanilla, biting lemon zest. finish is sour. wheatyness does not hold this together. lingering tinfoil finish that reminds me of bad bananas and zinc. thanks for sharing this fly.

Hope I can convey both my enjoyment of this beer and that of it being an example of why I feel larger samples help let one truly know what theyre sampling. If I could only post a graph that plotted my sensations and their evolution throughout tasting this. Split a 750 and initially was enamored by the earthy aroma and spiciness. The feeling proceeded to surge for a bit and then it seemed as if the carbonation had increased and the pleasure diminished to the point that I was almost getting bored with this. I feel bad saying this as it was a LONG week and perhaps its related to my exhausted state, but thats my honest assessment. I would however welcome another chance to try it. THANK YOU MATT(A)!

Bottle. Pale yellow color with a big foamy, fizzy white head. Nose is lots of peppery spicyness with some lemon. taste is peppery and spicy, bites the tongue a bit, lemon mixes in and brings some light sour fun sour notes. Finished with a nice refreshing bitterness and leaves your mouth lemony.

Somewhat of a tough category for me to rate, since I find Wits the be very one sided and boring. Still, this wasnt a bad brew. A hazy gold color, with copious white fluffy head. Notes of oak and yeast are prominent. Taste is rather nice, yeasty and citrusy, that finishes with a  perppery sweetness and good bubbling on the tongue.

Bottle. Hazy straw color with a large rocky white head that was lasting. Good complex citrus and spice. Medium body with complex texture. Light sweet malt and complex spice flavor and a long finish. Very interesting brew.

Pale straw yellow, slightly cloudy and with a decent white head fed by active carbonation.  Aroma is yeasty and spiced.  Clove and bananna are present.  Sweet malts also make an apperance.  The flavor is nice and fairly complex.  Malt sweetness and a light tangyness.  Bananna and clove spice is a noticable characteristic.  Its fruity and quite active on the palate with a wonderful tangy finish.

Very nice pour, a pale apricot body filled with vivacious bubbles that continually reinforce a dense, fizzy, cream colored head.  The aroma is all orange, both the juice and the peel. Its quite alive in the mouth, the lively carbonationation seeking to build a new head all the way through the gullet and into the stomach.  The flavor is more complex, a light Wheaties taste with orange zest, caramel, coriander, and soft spices.  It finishes on a mildly tart note.  This is good for a warm Summer day, or a warm October day like today.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

Fresh orange peel and coriander aroma.  Slightly hazy yellow color, bubbly white head that dissipated quickly.  Light crisp flavor, classic citrus/coriander, plus a unique vanilla-oak note.  Mdium light body, crisp and refreshing, perfect summer beer.  A classic witbier with an added complexity from some time on the oak.  Very good stuff.

Contented smiles around the table, our favorite beer of the evening.  Long lasting white head on top of a hazy yellow core surrounded by sparkling golden brew.  Corriander, pepper, lemon, summer fruits and spice aromas, theres a bit of hop in there too!  Body is soft and smooth, light but not prickly carbonation.  Taste is surprisingly floral with plenty of citrus, followed by a light hop and then the dry oaky finish - then the sweet summer fruits, citrus and sweets come back for an encore.  Fantastic.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 re-rate 8-14-07  i always said this is my least favorite JP, but i think it was because i didnt appreciate the Brett the 1st time round!  so here goes!
Sweet citrus on the nose, cinamon and nutmeg, lemon zest.  Pours very light blonde with a thin white head.  Sour orange, lemon zest, corriander, fades away into butter-like flavors.  I still preger Bam Bier, but it is better than i remembered!

Pours golden blonde, with a huge fluffy white head.  Heavily carbonated like Champagne.  Sweet and spicy aroma, the orange peel and corriander, some vanilla, cinamon.  Delicate sweet citrus at first, crisp dry finish.  Feels carnonated in mouth.  Not bad but not great..

Pours a dark yellow with a huge white head.  Nice aroma of coriander, white pepper, and banana.  Flavor of pepper, cloves, coriander and has a bunch (no pun intended) of banana flavor.  As the brew warms yeast and honey flavors emerge, with some earthy woodsiness.  Fizzy mouth feel, a bit heavier bodied than many whites, but it works well.  A very solid white.

Beautiful label art is in no way wasted on this terrific beer. She starts with a big, fizzy head over a golden/ciderish body, infused with constant champagne-effervescence. Aroma was slightly vinegared and overall yeasty with banana, clove, green grapes and bread dough. Crisply tart with a lively presence in the mouth. Creamy & dry mouthfeel makes it almost "fluffy".  Slightly sour to finish with clove. Delicate yet multi-layered and terribly intriguing.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a glowing gold colored brew that sits under a thick whipped cream head. Medium bodied with some slight floral notes , Spices are restrained almost to a fault as they seem to fade in the middle. Still a decent well made brew.

The perfect match for my tastes, I instantly fell in love. 
An appreciation for its old-world brewing style and oak-aging make revealing the subtle hints Curacao and coriander that much better. 

I am truly inspired by this ale.
Pours with a pale yellow body topped by a thick head with some lacing.  Its slightly sweet and malty with a huge floral note.  Medium bodied, smooth and dry.

I smell soap and sulpher meshed together in the aroma. That, needless to say, gets your attention. Pours a delicate pale gold with a light head that is more gas bubbles than froth. This takes many sips to get at flavor wise. Initially I thought I tasted faint bannana, but as I continued I decided it was just the effect fo the coriander and the malt and not quite the same as you would taste in say a german Hefe. There is a thinness to this that doesnt come until the final sip, but it tastes like spicy water at that final swallow and that loses points.

Still there is a very pleasing aftertaste to this that sticks with you and compells you to drink more.

Light yellow with standard haze and a really sticky, dense white head.  Great aroma.  Lots of yeasty notes, with crisp orange and lemon citrus.  The mouthfeel is very thin.  Flavors are almost a carbon copy of the aroma, but much less intense.  Tart, wheaty, yeasty finish.  High points and low points.
One of my Michigan favorites. From bottle (or at Michigan Summer Fest) on tap. Light, white-tasting beer with hint of coriander. Pours nicely.  Excellent brewery.
Faded yellow gold with a towering rocky head.  Overpowering coriander aroma.  Dry tart wheat flavor, pungent with spice.  Mouthfeel is light medium and rather dry.
Mich Ale fest 05.    Sweet grapefruit (like when your mom made them sit all night cut with sugar), like a dry champagne.  Nice drink
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Gold color with a thin white head.  Holy corriander, Batman!  Geez, Im a fan of the spice used in moderation but like anything else that gets out of hand, its a little wrong.  This tasted like they ground up corriander seeds, dumped them in a bottle, filled the cracks with water, and called it a whitbier.

Very nice beer.  A little dryer than Hoegarden-which is a plus in my book.  Having had two of their beers, my thought is just that theyre very very well made.  They almost taste like theyre handmade and you can kind of taste the difference.  Great stuff!!

Very light lemon yellow with a milky-like thickness and chunky yeast particles sludging around on the bottom of the glass. Medium standing bright white foam slowly dwindles to a thin creamy skim and collar. Moslty drippy lacing with some partial sheeting and strings stick.

Aroma is of a slightly musty bread dough. Airy and lofty with an unbreakable tint of lemon candy. Has a bit of melon and bitter orange zest along with a faint touch of corriander.

Mild mellow taste of lemon bread dough. Slightly spicy with breezings of herbal grasses, pepper, clove, and corriander. Light pale malt sweetness underneath. Moderately crisp and very easy going with mostly doughy lemon candy taking the front with the spices and light sweetness keeping to the edges. Nice but brief little sugary grab on the finish as the pale malt floats in with very soft and airy light drying.

Feel is light to medium body with a creamy crispness and doughy sweet center. Very pleasant carbonation thats mild and smooth. Not so much Witbier-like as it should be, but I like it none the less as its smoothness tends to favor my palate. Finish is intriguingly unique with its airy pale malt sweetness.

Pretty good stuff. A little out of the realm of most Witbiers, but likeable and damn drinkable all the same. At first I was skeptical, but its mild complexity grew on me. Good thing this comes in a bomber, otherwise 12oz may not have been enough to get a full scope of its easy goin, drinkin character.

Bottle sampled @ RBSG 05 (Montréal) Grand TastingYellow blonde, nice head, nice lacing. Nose of bright crispy fruit, some mild hops and some freshly milled malt dust. The flavor is clean, balanced, nice. Another one thats fairly tasty that Id rather drink than write about.

Pale yellow hue, edging that near-white that epitomizes the style, with an able, attractive cap of creamy foam.
Zesty nose, alive with spice, yeast, and citric fruit, lemon and orange.Very lively and likeable, and again, fully in the witbier paradigm.
Tenderly trips on the palate, sleek and slippery, awash with coriander, ginger, and fruit. So light, it dances along the tastebuds, but keeps them happy with delicately delicious flavors.
A top-notch effort from a brewery to keep your eye on!

Bottles acquired in trades with iwantalambic & Styles (thanks!). Poured a medium and hazy golden color with an averaged sized head. Aromas of spices, yeast and light lemons and oranges. Tastes of lemons, spices and wheat. Light to medium sweet with a dry and crisp finish. Lighter body.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2005 Couleur dorée, apparence trouble et brouillée, moyenne quantité de mousse.  Arômes plaisantes et axés sur les épices style clou de girofle, cardamome et gingembre...ainsi que de fruits rappelant les raisins verts, les litchis, les bananes et les poires.  Passablement sucrée en bouche, phénols épicés, citrons, coriandre et levure à profusion.  Corps dépaisseur moyenne, finale sucrée.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2005 RBSG 2005: Poured yellow with a small white head. Light yeasty aroma with hints of banana and lemon in the flavor. Mild hops. Refreshing drink that I thought was quite nice.

(750ml bottle) Sampled at RBSG 2005 in Montreal. Frothy white head with a clear, straw-coloured and highly-carbonated body. Nose of velvety wheat. The flavour of bananas melting into vanilla makes this a fantastic find.

Thanks to BierBauch for the 750 ml of goodness.  Pour is lots of a head and a bubbling lemon hue beneath.  Aroma is a musky lemon spice.  Mouthfeel is zesty yet ends very soft and gentle.  Flavor is smooth and easy going as well.  Malt profile is medium, spice flavor is minimal and there is no bite to it other than a little bit of orange zest.  This would go quite well with some salmon or tastey white fish.

(750ml bottle) Hazy straw body topped by a white gusher of a head (that takes too long to settle).  Aroma is fairly pungent -- medium sweet, lemon, orange peel, some pepper.  Taste is medium sweet, lemon peel, wheat, coriander.  Watery light body.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2006 12-oz. bottle, consumed May 2006.
I just wanted to sit back, relax and revel in this beers glory, now that I can enjoy a 12-oz. bottle of it at any ol time.  Hence, no thorough rerate, but Ive bumped up the rating to reflect my amplified enjoyment of the increased tart acidity that the barrel imparts more heavily as time goes by  the wild yeast impartations are much more prevalent than in the earlier batches of this biere blanche, and for that, any numerous other reasons, I fin love it!750-ml. bottle, consumed June 2005.Lightly hazy gold in color with a short, bubbly white head.  Aroma is wondrous, revealing cloves, orange peel, lemon zest, mild pepper, and fresh lemon poppy seed muffins.  Very refreshing flavor.  You can taste the oaken smoothness fresh off the bat, and it serves as a mellowing agent to the traditional citric shine.  Uniquely creamy unlike any other wit.  Sweet cloves, ginger and lemon poppy seeds fill in the rest to balance this beer extremely well.  Finish is like creamy lemon ice with a smoothness hinting at oak and leather.  Very nice.

Pours hazy golden with a huge white head.   Aroma is of hay, pear, cider, slight creamy banana. Flavor is hay, sweet pear and peach, cream. Dry finish, Body is light but creamy. The finish is very thin which is possibly the only negative part of this otherwise very nice wit.

Bottle, 750 mL:  Golden colored, well carbonated, very large white foamy head.  Aroma is of mellow wheat, yeast, citrus, hay and grass.  Flavor is light and airy spiciness, sweet light fruit, wheat.  Mouth feel is tickling/tingling.

the color is dark straw, out of a 750 mL bottle.  spicy peppery wheat aroma, probably coriander and citrus, with yeast and a touch of malt.  very carbonated, and this is a great-looking beer with a convection of sheeting bubbles constantly rising to the top.  tastes incredibly pale, with mostly typical wit flavors.  fruity/estery, but not quite funky like some lambics get.  an extremely well-done belgian style, another impressive beer from jolly pumpkin!

Pours a light cloudy orange, almost gold color. The white head is huge. The aroma is banana peels with oranges and coriander. There is also some grassy freshness. Very refreshing aroma. The taste is orange peels and grass. The coriander spicing is very light, but just there enough to keep you interested. There is also an underlying banana and passion fruit tropical character. This is incredibly well balanced and subtly delicious.

Belgian wheat aroma. Pale gold in color with tons of rushing carbonation. Huge, white head; mostly lasting. Great lace. Hazy body. Light on flavor. I didnt pick up the coriander or orange peel. Dry. Technically sound, but flavor is as much like a pale lager as a Belgian white. Better as it warms, but not JPs best offering.

Hazy light straw color with a moderate white head. Mild wit aromas drift about, with mild zest and coriander, light pale malts and hints of cloves and herbal flowers. Light malt backs up the spice. Sweet pale malt and light coriander, hints of vanilla and orange blossom honey. I like this because it has hit the balances well. A difficult style to even come close in and this one has hit things solidly (or should I say lightly, as it is neither overpowering nor weak). Just a solid wit. Easily one of the best in the States since the old Celis.
hazy golden colored w/ a fluffy white heat, this is a nice white ale. A touch too much carbonation for me, but the citrus flavors and crispness make this an enjoyable warm weather beer.

Pale yellow with a white head like beaten egg whites.  Very lively on the palate with a light, spicey nose.  This is a light and refreshing beer with notes of corriander spice and subtle citrus flavors.  Very nice beer and something that I could drink everyday.

Hazy yellow color.  Lofty foam.  Light spice (orange peel, coriander), with hints of banana, wheat malt and butter toffee in the nose.  Fairly pleasant tasting, with hints of vanilla and raw spicing.  Yet another approachable witbier, but if this were a little stronger and more flavorful it could be so much better.
started out nicely with the typical citrus,mild spice and yeast. Turned kinda funky and had a way too dry finish that just ruined it and left me with cotton mouth. BLAH!

750ml. Glowing cloudy golden ale with a thick white head that retains well. Peppery aroma with spices of clove and some nice funky yeast notes. Orange and coriander are very faint and Id prefer them up front and in your face. Body is soft, smooth and very much to style. I did notice a slight chalky dry finish in this one. Flavor is nice with good yeast flavors as well as spicy notes. This is a very good brew but Id like some more orange and coriander up front like Hoegaarden.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: (750ml bottle)  Pours a lightly cloudy yellow body with a large egg-white head.  Aroma of a beauty salon (perm), spicy yeast, grain, and some fruit and spices.  Flavor of banana, doughy, and spices.  Soft, creamy mouthfeel.
Tasted at the Dark Lord release party.Really light yellow,almost glow in the dark yellow.Smells almost of hay and cloves.This came off a little sour with that lingering hay flavor.
Mt Dew yellow and slightly hazy. A rather subtle wit, a bit heavy on the bananas but still quite quaffable.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2013 Thanks to JSquire!  AP: HUGE foamy merengue like head.  Neon green tinge on the body.  Huge lacing.  Weird, but cool.  Ar: spicy, coriander, clove, cardamom, orange peel, barnyard.F: Wheat, cardamom, clove, spicy.  good.P: Highly carbonated. Tart. Medium-light mouthfeel.9, 5, 8, 4, 17 = 4.3
Resampled.  The aroma is too strong.  The barnyard is a bit too apparent.  The appearance is a bit too "plain".  The flavor and the palate are unchanged.  Dropped the overall a little bit. 7, 4, 8, 4, 15 = 3.8

Hazy and brightly golden with a big and fluffy, lasting head. Spicy, clean and inviting nose carries with it light herbs. Soft carbonation; lightish body. Chewy yeast flavors. Light fruit (orange, lemon, and maybe some passion). Doughy malts. Mild bitterness. Mellow beer, but flavorful and well made.

Pours a bright golden with a frothy white head with some clumpy lacing.  Aroma is very authentically Belgian, with lots of dry peppery spice and a touch of sweet crystal malt.  Body starts semi-sweet, with lots of filling, finely dissolved carbonation toward a mild, candy-like finish with hints of coriander.  A very nice, and quite drinkable witbier.  Thanks to both wohlfs and silphium for the bottles!

Fizzy white head, slightly cloudy golden color body. Musty aroma of orange peel, coriander, lemon. Light to medium body. Slightly sweet palate, subdued lemon and a nice drying, bitter finish. Very clean.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2007 Bottle.

Head is initially small, fizzy, white, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy light yellow, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (herbs), lightly yeasty (cobwebs, barnyard), with light notes of coriander, lemon and lime zest, autumn leaves, minerals.

Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Pleasant, spritzy, quaffing wit.  Great balance and aroma (kind of wild, as are most of JPs stuff, which works well here).

Beer pours cloudy medium golden with a well retained egg white head.  Aroma is BIG coriander and orange peel, white pepper and yeast.  Flavor is what you would expect from the aroma.  Light sweetness with lots of spices, bit of orange flavor, also light wheat flavor.  A wonderful beer for summertime.  I will be serving this in the backyard in August.
Pours rather clear with a lot of carbonation.  Light, crisp, and fizzy.  A bit drier than a normal Belgian Wit.
I need to rerate this, but for now here are my definitely jaded-palate impressions. Lemony whaet aromas with some coriander spice poking through. Malty with a long finish and some decent carbonation.
cloudy yellow, white head.  coriander spicy lemony nose.  wheaty malt flavour and orange/lemon citrus with backing spice.  sprtizy mouthfeel.  nice wit.

Bottle pours a dull yellow, not as pale as I would have expected, somewhat cloudy, large white foamy head, with fairly attractive lacing. &nbsp Citrusy nose, corriander, and some spices. &nbsp Somewhat dull spicy/citrusy character on the tongue. &nbsp Not as sharp or crisp as I would have thought. &nbsp It is very clean however. &nbsp Wheaty mouthfeel, decent body albeit not as flavorful as others. &nbsp Finishes with very soft citrus and very light corriander. &nbsp Needs to be spiced more, otherwise decent. &nbsp Thanks goes out to CaptainCougar for the trade!

Ill start by saying Ive always had a place in my heart for a good wit.  Lightly hazed golden, fizzy white head.  Nice soft nose of orange zest, corriander, pepper, lemon, and wheat.  Similar flavors, was very well balanced, with a light hop bitterness rounding this out.  Medium bodied, zesty carbonation, drying orangey, wheaty finish.  Nice stuff.  Special thanks to llgrgg for bringing this back from MI....

Bottle... Hazy, straw-colored ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Good retention and weeping lace. The nose is of grilled, unhusked corn, unmalted grain and white pepper. The flavor is perfectly balanced, but very non-descript. Light-bodied and fizzy. Short, crisp, clean finish.

Large white head, large bubbled with a short life span and minimal laceing. Hazy straw blond color with a soft white glow. Spicey, herbaly nose, lightly citrusy, oranges and a hint of ripe pears. Light body, gentle carbonation. Clean citrus flavors, coriander, yeasty, mildly acidic, bready malts, faint vanilla notes and mabe some light woody notes in the background. Finish is almost dry, lightly fruity. Thanks to JCW for a shot at this fine brew.

Bottle at Fall Beerfest In Toronto 2004.  Hazy yellow in colour.  Aroma was quite spicy, lots of citrus (oranges and lemons), and coriander.  The flavour was very spicy with pepper, citrusy (oranges again),  light yeastyness.  Large mouthfeel, medium body, mild carbonation.  Finishes with a mild bitterness, dry.

Bottle. Thanks to wohlfs for this! Cloudy gold. Small dense white head. Aroma is coriander, lime, pepper, other spices, and light yeast. Light banana notes as well. Taste is spice and light citrus with wheat, yeast, light honey notes, grains and light wood. Body is medium but still refreshing. Somewhat rich at times as well. Ends dry. Finish is light spice and wheat, fruit esters, hints of sourdough, light hay or grass, and more light wood. Nice wit, probably the best wit Ive ever had!

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2005 Mildly hazy, rich banana-colored body with a tight sudsy white head. Herbal coriander-lime aroma plus some pepper spice, orange, fruity esters, hay, and light notes of clove and barnyard. Wild, funky elements in the flavor. Tastes like limes, candied orange peels and honey. Comes across as sweet to me with a lot of pale malt and honey character, but I think its actually deceptively dry. A touch too phenolic perhaps. Considerable body with nice fullness for a wit-like beer. A very solid, complex and creative spinoff of the style.

Big Thanks to BBB63 for this brew! Pours  a hazy golden color.  Nice white bubbly head.  Aroma is is full of oranges, corriander, other spices,  and wheat, with a little "barnyard" in there as well.  Flavor is very nice, lots of spices and a little fruity/acidic/dry finish. Just slightly sour, possibly from the fruits/yeast or aging. Very nice and easy to drink!

Behemoth thanks to BBB63 and footbalm for this.  Its a damn good thing they both sent a bottle, because Ill either drink the other one tomorrow or ransom it for a new Playstation2.  Poured into a Hennepin glass, turbid deep urine yellow color with an off-white head and hop floaties.  Aroma of malt, Brett, barnyard, hops and citrus.  Tastes citrusy, with a solid malt and hop presence, some Brett, and yeast.  Very smooth, with citrus and fruit at the finish.  Just fabulous.  Very complex and well balanced, and the complexity increases as it warms.  As I finished it, I came damn close to uncapping the other bottle, but Ill save that for a special occasion.  If you rated this below a 4.0 or so, then you just dont get it! (with all due respect).

750:  A light, not hazy, golden.  Actually, the lack of haziness was somewhat of a put off.  Fairly wheaty, but the lack of haziness in appearness carried over to a lack of "haziness" in the flavor, that Ive come to associate with wits.  Overall, however, well crafted, just not the pinacle of wits.

750ml bottle: Poured to a hazy golden hue with an initially large fizzy head which settled to a small ring but never quits and produced some fine lace on my NB snifter. The aroma has some wonderful notes of corriander, clove, white pepper, orange zest, wheat, slightly funky and earthy yeast esters. The taste didnt disappont either with a big spicy forefront with a nice moderate citric and wheaty backbone. Discovered some earthy and herbal notes through to the surprisely bone dry finish (due to the barrel aging?) and melon aftertaste and lingering pepper tones. The feel is very crisp and lively, perhaps a bit too much as it make it seem somewhat watery. The carbonation does keep this more akin to the refreshing nature of the style so Im not going to deduct a lot for this observation. Overall, this is one top-notch wit that is worthy of all praise. Among the best found in America. The more I drink it , the more Im digging it.

Pours a hazy gold-orange color, it is topped by a frothy off white, creamy head that is held up by an ample carbonation.  The aroma is spicy with orange peel dominating, but there are notes of ginger, pepper, a hint of musty cobwebs, earthy coriander, and a bright citrus acidity.  The aroma is quite nice.

The beer is nice and light on the palate.  It starts with a citrusy orange character and finishes with a bright acidity, that moves to an herbal perhaps woody tannic note.  There is a nice light wheat character here that mixes well with the other refreshing components of this beer. This really is quite well done actually, at first it seems like a straight up Belgian Wit, but there are subtle notes of complexity here, and I do believe that there is perhaps a bit more acidity than is typical of the more simplistic Witbiers out there.  This beer has lots of good spiciness to it as well, I get notes of ginger, pepper, coriander.  I like that the coriander is used correctly in this beer, it is not too strong and the earthy-herbal note that is typical of overly-spiced versions is held nicely in check.

This is definitely one of the best Belgian Wits that I have had, I am a sucker for a good Wit, but I think that this has struck a really nice balance.  It is bright, citrusy, and quite refreshing, yet it has some subtle complexity to it, but not so much that it gets in the way of this beer being refreshing like it should.  Hopefully the barrels that this beer is aged in will be properly inoculated, because this could use a bit more funky complexity to it, that would definitely make this beer perfection in the glass come late spring to summer time.  This is by far the best beer from Jolly Pumpkin that I have had, This is in fact just a world class example of this style, and I hope this brewery can get their Barrels going such that all of their beers can get to this level.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2005 750 ml bottle imbibed with joy alongside MartinT, tiggmtl and Rastacouere.  Hazy light blonde, with a medium lasting head...huge zesty nose offers vanilla, ginger, cumin and orangepeel, a complexity of spice beyond the typical wit...the body alas doesnt quite hold up, being predominantly orangy-lemony, too dry at the finish and with too much carbonation...still well above average and if this is the worst this brewer can do, he has only the sky as a limit!

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2005 The Lure:Beauteous grapefruit pulp acting as a moat around the elegant spicing of levitating ginger, freshly-cut coriander leaves, white pepper and dessert-loving cloves. Perfumes meld and traverse the mind.

The Festivities:Doughy yeast attempts to ground the frolicking spices but a fervent effervescence propulses them to orgiastic intensity. Lemonade soothes the tongue and orange zest palpates the palate. Dryness ensues, encouraged by the puffy carbonation.

Transcendence:
What a delight it is to find a unique treasure trove in the fields of a solitary farm.

Nice cloudy gold, rather dark for a white beer, gentle meringous head, sticking to the edges. Incredible spicy aroma, executed with grace. It seems so easy, this is troubling. Firm ginger roots, fresh ginseng, mellow coriander and a touch of lemon and vanilla combine into the most gracious offering. The closest one I can think of would be hitachinos, but more subtle and elegant. Like a spice mousse, fluffy. Unfortunately, the flavor doesnt quite hold up though its still far better than most contenders in the style. It is surprisingly bitter and has a sharp sour/vinous middle with rhubarb, ginger and cranberry notes. I dont find the same coherence than in the aroma, but this may be due to the agressive carbonation, full of big bubbles, which somehow detracts a bit. Nonetheless a stunning take on a witbier, world-class and beyond aroma.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2005 Original Rating (9-3-7-3-16=3.8): Orange, lemon, citrus aroma is very spicy with notes of coriander, oak and vanilla.  Hazy yellow body is topped by a decent, fine-bubbled, white head that recedes to lasting cover.  Flavour is very fresh - like a spring garden or gazpatcho soup with a crisp, dry finish and fair bitterness.  Fair carbonation but heavy feeling in the mouth.  Bottle enjoyed with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.Rerate (8-3-7-2-14=3.4): Tangerine, coriander and ginger are prominent in the wheaty, dusty aroma.  Hazy, orange-gold with a low white head that recedes to a lasting cover.  Ginger, coriander, spruce  and orange flavour the wheaty base.  Medium body with somewhat low carbonation.  Bottle sampled with MartinT, Olivier_MTL and Rastacouere.

Slighlty hazed golden body topped by a white meraingue head. Glass lacing is superb. Spicy sweet banana aroma. The flavor is very nice, light sourness, yeasty esthers throughout, and a lighlty bitter hoppy finsih. Dry medium-light palate. Nice stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2005 Absolutely delicious.  This stuff is the best white ale in the U.S. -- dethroning another Michigan favorite, Celis.  Brilliant luminescent gold with a tinge of ol redheadhead ... a strawberry blonde.  Sour and zippy aroma tinged with some citrus and yeast.  Delectable sweet finish which with some hoppiness.  A very pronounced sense of freshness.  This is a spring beer, no doubt about it, celebrating zymurgic life.  Grand.
Light blonde cloudy color, with a rich sudsy head.  Sour but fruity smell.  Taste of bananna. A good session beer works well with shrimp cocktail. ;)

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2006 Cloudy light yellow with a nice banana nose & head retention. Taste is perfectly balanced with a warm caramel taste. Followed up with a sweet yeastiness. Really drinkable, sweet and dry. I find the 12 oz bottle to be a bit more on the sour side with some lemon, more bret and less head retention. Still good but a few slashes off for head retention from the 750.
Yeast and wheat aroma, hazy yellow/gold, small white head. Soft wheat, a tiny bit spicey. Light bodied, refreshing. Fair.  Thank You wohlfs and qdog.
Golden colour with a strong white head. Light and dry aroma of citrus, banana & ginger, all of which appear in the flavour as well. A little too tart in the finish.  [Toronto Christmas Party 04]
Gold brew with medium white head .  Dusty , dirty aroma .  Wit base with hopp accents  . Short, dry end..
Pale straw color, bright white head. Spritzy, lightly spiced, some lemon. Lighter malt, ginger. Light bodied, but it worked okay for the beer. A decent wit.
Hazy yellow-gold w/ bright white head & good lace. Light, spritzy aroma of lemon, ginger, banana, cloves, & solvent. Light, mildly gritty feel. Flavour is lightly malty & wheaty w/ a dry, lemony zip.
Carbonation on tongue, with lemon and bitterness in there. Corriander, ginger and spices moderated by malt dose. Thanks to Wohlfs at Doug Shoemakers  tasting.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2007 Re-rate, new #s 3/07
Nose is JP yeasty funk, lemon, wood, fruit, really bright.  Flavor is lemony light bread, yeast, earthy.


Old rating: 6/3/4/3/10
Thanks to whoever brought this to the Toronto Christmas Party 04.  Super clear tan w. a thin white head.  Lemon & ginger.  I find this too bitter.  Lemon, yeast, astringent.  Meh.

Cool label. Golden body, with a moderate fluffy white head. Subtle aroma is lightly spiced lemon, with an unfortunate hint of solvent in the background. Flavour is very dry, with spicey peppery notes over wheat. Light palate for the style.  A nice beer that didnt do much for me at the time.

I must Thank our fellow rater wohlfs for sending me the foursome of Jolly Pumpkin beers! 
Rating # 635
The White Pumpkin has a most beautiful appearance... its a pretty "Squash." The body is a glowing golden Calabaza with a fine-looking white cap of head. There is an intense sheet of finely compacted bubbles that lace the inner glass. The aroma puts forth a tart lemony and yeasty beady-ness. The flavor brings delicate notes of clove and coriander, but the citric lemony likeness and a hint of ginger are still in the forefront. This Witt has the traditional musty cracked wheat flavor that I find in most well made Belgian style Witbiers, it embraces that earthy, organic feeling. The palate brings a most amazing feeling of light effervescence all throughout my mouth; its light yet hearty viscosity is very refreshing! 
 In all Honestly, this is undoubtedly the most amazing Witt I have ever had! I do not know where or by whom the brewer at Jolly Pumpkin studied; but in my mind, he or she has created the most traditional and enjoyable Witt I have ever sampled and Im generally not a fan of this style!

750 mL capped bottle, courtesy of the very generous Jeff (TAR) and Emily (cb): crystalline lemon gold body, it simply glows in the sunlightperfect white cream  dense, fluffy and retentive.  Strong hay presence in the aroma is wrapped by lemon zest, soft wheat, pine nuts, coriander and pale malt, complexly rich and amazing, dare I say: memorizing.  Brilliantly soft and tingly on the tongue, hundreds of tiny bubbles rushing in a smooth stream into all corners of the mouth.  There is a nice play of lively fizz and smooth, creamy carbonation.  Toasted coriander flavours blend elegantly with freshly cracked pepper, sourdough yeast and fresh wild flowers.  Wow, how gracious Jeff & EmilyThank you!
medium brown, yellowish appearance; no head whatsoever; palate is very smooth; a light lemony flavor with a somewhat woody aftertaste; a very refreshing beer

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2005 Pours a little cloudy yellow. Nice head that lasts awhile. A little foot in the nose with some banana and pepper? Light orange/fruit flavor fading to spices/lots of pepper and maybe a little wood from the barrel. Dry spicy finish. Very nice overall.

Another gift of Jeff and Emily.  Hazy, golden yellow with a sizable, fluffy, white head.  The aroma is pleasingly soft and subtle.  Banana, citrus zest, coriander, wheat bread, fruity esters from the yeast and a bit of white pepper.  The body is light and refreshing which makes for easy drinking.  The flavor is quite nice with a bit of sweetness of front before a light tart finish accompanied by the slightest hint of hops.  Tasty and enjoyable.  Something I would drink with regularity in the summer, if I could only it get it regularly.

Cloudy yellow-orange body, thin off-white head.  Nose of coriander, banana, and orange peel.  Sharp body with little evidence of barrel aging at first, starting with banana, coriander, and wheat tang.  The finish is long and spicy; wood flavors also develop and leave a clean, dry mouthfeel.  To be honest I expected a bit more from this beer; as it stands, this is still a solid witbier, although I wish it was fuller-bodied and more complex.

BottleL  Strong citrus aroma and light clove.  Hazy pale yellow with a big white head.  Good retention.  Lots of citrus up front with a light clove and banana finish.  Finishes sweet with just a hint of sourness.
I tried this while visiting relatives near the brewery. Not very nice, bad aftertaste. I would not drink again.

Bottle. White head, sparse lacing, transparent, fast rising carbonation, and a pale yellow hue. Malty, spicy and some clove notes. Flavor was sweet, malty and tart. Mouthfeel was tingly. Medium bodied beer.

Pours a nice vibrant color with a rimming white head.  Aroma is sour and acidic, really nice bitter citrus peel.  Flavor is really great, like a spicy orange zest pancake, yeasty goodness.  Body excellent.  I likie.

Light, chilled apricot color.  Clunky looking white head.  Orange peel nose with a dash of white pepper.  The white pepper comes through in the taste.  Theres also a bit of citric sweetness -- like orange juice with some sugar.  The mouthfeel was kind of flat.  One of the better witbiers Ive had in some time.

Coudy straw/pale yellow with the most enormous and pillowy white head. Soury nose has touches of spice and pepper. Medium, satisfying body, a tangy wit, lemon and grains of paradise sneak through the malty middle. Fabulous complexity, strong contender for my favorite beer of the month!  I cannot wait until these barrels start producing an even tangier beer!
bottle, golden orange in color, white head that dissipated fairly quickly, definitely wheaty in taste and smell with a twinge of sourness, slight smell and taste of fruit

Bottle.  Pours a hazy deep yellow color, bordering on orange.  Modest head, white in color.  Aroma is fruity and more.  Smells somewhat like herbal tea.  Very nice!  Taste is wheat malt, yeast, and spices.  Very well done.  I wish I would have tried this sooner.  This would be an excellent summer beer.

Hazy yellow colored, pours with a frothy white head.  Aroma was fo yeasty, banana, spicey and slighty citrus(like lemon).  Light bodied and bubbley.  It does have a moderate sweetness to the flavor. Wet and sweet finish.  Nice Wit, thanks TAR

Dark hazy lemon. Quarter-inch beaming white foam with scattered rocky patches. Remarkably integrated aroma of coriander, white grapes, glazed pale malt, and peppery yeast. Rosehips, jellied orange peels, and extremely bright Hallertauer notes. Soft and fluffy carbonation.  Succulent body. Sweet pils malt structure is overlapped by plump orange pulp acidity. Touches of medicine and slightly astringent yeast coarsen the juicy body. Hops are deceptively juicy, throughout, acquiring a rich, yet tangy, lemon balm underlay. Doughy yeast coats the roof of the mouth, seemingly thickening the body, with waning pils malt and heightening coriander. Vague malt hull flavor comes in late alongside rosehips and some raw cane sugar grit. Moist ending, with assorted tropical fruits, floral hops, and doughy yeast elements. Astonishing complexity, but oh so refreshing. Superb!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: JUL 29, 2006 Rererate: Lacto sourness precludes getting to the original flavor, at least in the summer 2005 botlings which are now in OH, for example. Flavor and aroma downgrades...bummer! Rerate: several samplings later. Downgrade slightly in flavor. Original, August 2004. Bottled, purchased at the brewery from Ron Jeffries after a nice conversation. This is truly a fantastic wit, and a lucky and great choice for #50 of the style. I think this is the best American made witbier I have ever had, bar none. The misty nose straight from the bottledneck was such a clean hit of coriander the hairs on the back of my neck stood up. Strong, acrid wheat malt melts into smooth orange and big spicy pepper and coriander in the nose. Looks perfectly luminescent golden, lit from within. Loads of yeast in the bottom, swirl vigorously to get it all in the last load of the snifter. All the elements are clearly distinguishable here, even the pepper and coriander flavor bursts - the tip of my tongue is still tingling. Oak aging has softened the flavors some, and the body is nearly as full as the best overseas wits (BFMs comes to mind). Delightful, and far better than expected given my like for, but not raving reviews of, the other Jolly Pumpkin ales.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 22, 2007 Batch 1 draught fresh at MBGSBF July 2004Pours a very dull, hazed pale white gold.  Small head, mostly disipating.  Aroma of oak, wet leather, yeast, coriander.  Flavor is toasty and oaky from the white oak aging, but some of the coriander and yeast breaks through and further dries out the palate.  There was a bittersweet finish, some hops and light malt (honey, white bread).  Didnt find much citrus (orange peel or lemon) in this one, but thats alright.  Still unsure how I feel about the oak aging.  Body was medium-full, lightly spritzy.2006 and later bottlesMuch improved, though also much different with the wild yeasts being present.  New score/comments forthcoming.
